This is a procedural review to tag a final release for each deliverables ; and

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

because image_chunks = None when the image isn't found."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2016-04-18 05:13:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

@steven
Sorry, your comments don't make sense to me.  So if this doesn't fix the problem we will have to sync up.  The problem with your initial patch is that some of the calls (delete for example) are expecting a None return value; your change caused this to raise when it shouldn't, unless I'm missing something."}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-04-18 08:05:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

John,

its probably easier to have a live conversation on IRC.  I'll find you Monday if possible.

Frankly I'm not sure this is a good/right idea. I find it odd that Glance can have multiple nodes and not require they be synced and punt that off to consumers to figure out how to deal with?  But maybe I'm misunderstanding something; it seems like really crappy behavior.

Meanwhile, I'm also very curious if/how Nova deals with this situation, because they should have the exact same problem; unless having the local cache of the image keeps it from happening."}, {'account_id': 21193, 'date': '2016-04-19 02:24:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> Frankly I'm not sure this is a good/right idea. I find it odd that
 > Glance can have multiple nodes and not require they be synced and
 > punt that off to consumers to figure out how to deal with?  But
 > maybe I'm misunderstanding something; it seems like really crappy
 > behavior.
 > 
 > Meanwhile, I'm also very curious if/how Nova deals with this
 > situation, because they should have the exact same problem; unless
 > having the local cache of the image keeps it from happening.

Nova also has this same problem with image retrieval from glance.  The typical solution people adopt is either retry all glance services, or use a third party replication service in glance.  Obviously the third party replication service is suboptimal.

See:
https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/master/ansible/roles/nova/templates/nova.conf.j2#L100

Note we typically tell people to use a replicated storage backend such as ceph, where this isn't a problem.  Surguei wants to add lvm storage backend and this is the solution Kolla uses for non-replicated backends."}, {'account_id': 15831, 'date': '2016-04-20 11:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Build succeeded.

- infortrend-cinder-volume-iscsi http://openstack.infortrend.com/56/306756/7/check/infortrend-cinder-volume-iscsi/9fee94d : SUCCESS in 2h 25m 09s
- infortrend-cinder-volume-fc http://openstack.infortrend.com/56/306756/7/check/infortrend-cinder-volume-fc/ba8b3b1 : SUCCESS in 2h 23m 07s'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-04-20 13:17:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

fwiw the kola project acknowledges with a file backend, there is no HA available anywhere in the persistent storage.  Our answer to persistent storage HA is "Use Ceph" which we implement today.

This is more about correct operation for horizontal scalability.  When one wants to horizontally scale cinder (or nova or any other service that uses glance) it is necessary to contact every glance service to find the correct one with the stored image.

I personally feel this is a design flaw of glance, but it is what is.  That is why those glance retries are i there, to handle the condition that the glance service doesn't have the actual data and we need to find the data from a different service.

Nove-api on the other hand will forward the request to the correct compute service with the persistent storage, which is correct design.

Regards
-steve'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2016-04-20 13:39:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@Steven: Horizontal scalability in that case should be addressed by for example consistent hash ring. Retrying until I hit a correct node is terribly inefficient and therefore doesn't solve scaling. Can't Kolla just use Swift as the simplest Glance backend? See also the discussion on the actual bugreport [1].

[1] https://launchpad.net/bugs/1571211"}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-06-21 15:29:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> @Steven: Horizontal scalability in that case should be addressed by
 > for example consistent hash ring. Retrying until I hit a correct
 > node is terribly inefficient and therefore doesn't solve scaling.
 > Can't Kolla just use Swift as the simplest Glance backend? See also
 > the discussion on the actual bugreport [1].
 > 
 > [1] https://launchpad.net/bugs/1571211


I agree the current approach is inefficient, but I am after something that works rather then something that is fast.  We had a cat today in the channel wanting to use some cinder plugin with lvm iscsi and he can't deploy multinode because of this problem.  We already recommend ceph as a storage backend so this problem doesn't exhibit.  However, not everyone wants to deploy ceph, and by transitive logic, not everyone wants to deploy swift either :)

Every operator uses this as a workaround to the fact that glance doesn't actually synchronize images between its various nodes."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2016-06-21 16:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-06-21 18:21:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

> I agree the current approach is inefficient, but I am after something that works rather then something that is fast.  We had a cat today in the channel wanting to use some cinder plugin with lvm iscsi and he can't deploy multinode because of this problem.  We already recommend ceph as a storage backend so this problem doesn't exhibit.  However, not everyone wants to deploy ceph, and by transitive logic, not everyone wants to deploy swift either :)

I understand that, but I believe Glance was never designed to be used like that. If a cloud is configured that way, how does the user check image properties? He has admin's rights and modifies Keystone's service catalog on his own to point to each of the Glance API instances until he hits the correct one? He hacks Glance client to loop over API servers?

> Every operator uses this as a workaround to the fact that glance doesn't actually synchronize images between its various nodes.

It doesn't because it's not Glance job. It is Swift's or whatever's Glance backend you're using.

If operator really wants file backend with multiple glance-api's, then NFS is the answer."}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2016-06-22 08:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

And by the way we should probably deprecate specifying Glance API endpoints in config and switch to use only Keystone catalog.'}, {'account_id': 22416, 'date': '2016-06-22 12:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

"If operator really wants file backend with multiple glance-api's, then NFS is the answer." 
Ok, what about if operator enabled external swift as backend (supported option), and then wants to use glance-cache ?[all in Multinode setup]
glance-cache-manage , and glance-cache-prefetcher still uses round robin to access api's :/
Feels like it should be addressed by glance folks.'}, {'account_id': 21193, 'date': '2016-06-23 11:08:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Other than philosophical or taking high-ground positions... can I ask those that object what the harm is? 

The only argument seems to be "you shouldn't do this", "you should use Ceph or NFS" which are bull shit answers IMO.

Is there a negative cost associated here?  Are we saying container deployments like Kolla should only work with Ceph and NFS (that's crap).'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2016-06-27 09:36:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Other than philosophical or taking high-ground positions... can I ask those that object what the harm is? 
> The only argument seems to be "you shouldn't do this", "you should use Ceph or NFS" which are bull shit answers IMO.

From my perspective the harm here is encouraging people to rely on false assumptions. See comment [1] - Glance team actually decided that multi-node deployments of Glance with file backend are not supported.

> Is there a negative cost associated here?  Are we saying container deployments like Kolla should only work with Ceph and NFS (that's crap).

I don't understand how different are container deployments from bare-metal ones in this context? I think it is totally possible to deploy Swift in Kolla [2].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1571211/comments/15
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/kolla/swift-guide.html'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-07-22 21:55:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Michal,

I don't have very good technical depth in Cinder, so please excuse my ignorance, but its my understanding that a whole lot of third party cinder drivers use iSCSI to integrate with Cinder.  I know for example that 3par + Kolla + HA is a non-starter - this was after the company spent a whole lot of money on 3par gear.

If an individual uses iSCSI to integrate Cinder with their legacy storage systems, they are essentially cut out of being able to operate with glance until this change merges.  I don't know how many iSCSI integrations there are, but I'd think atleast 3par would care.

Hope the context helps why we need this change."}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2016-07-25 13:59:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

 >

 >

But what prevents you from running Swift cluster as a Glance store and use 3PAR as Cinder backend? I don't understand how iSCSI Cinder driver means a necessity to run multiple glance-api with file backends. Can you elaborate more on that?"}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-07-25 15:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > Michal,
 > >
 > > I don't have very good technical depth in Cinder, so please
 > excuse
 > > my ignorance, but its my understanding that a whole lot of third
 > > party cinder drivers use iSCSI to integrate with Cinder.  I know
 > > for example that 3par + Kolla + HA is a non-starter - this was
 > > after the company spent a whole lot of money on 3par gear.
 > >
 > > If an individual uses iSCSI to integrate Cinder with their legacy
 > > storage systems, they are essentially cut out of being able to
 > > operate with glance until this change merges.  I don't know how
 > > many iSCSI integrations there are, but I'd think atleast 3par
 > would
 > > care.
 > >
 > > Hope the context helps why we need this change.
 > 
 > But what prevents you from running Swift cluster as a Glance store
 > and use 3PAR as Cinder backend? I don't understand how iSCSI Cinder
 > driver means a necessity to run multiple glance-api with file
 > backends. Can you elaborate more on that?

Your right in that you could configure CEPH or some other distributed store with Glance, but if you were to do that, why bother with hardware storage gear only for Cinder in the first place?

The fundamental requirement I see is folks buy storage gear - they want ALL storage on that gear - not some on 3par and some on swift backed by disks all over storage nodes.

The reality is the architecture you describe would never be deployed in the field because of a variety of concerns, risk being most visible.  This is why glance's strategy of "ignoring" file backed storage is a non-starter in the minds of operators.

Further Kolla operators don't typically agree with the argument you have made (use two types of storage for the same OpenStack).  This is one reason OpenStack has a reputation as a disjointed set of things rather then one clean-cut architecture.

Regards
-steve'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2016-07-26 12:58:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

 > Your right in that you could configure CEPH or some other

 > bother with hardware storage gear only for Cinder in the first
 > place?
 > 
 > The fundamental requirement I see is folks buy storage gear - they
 > want ALL storage on that gear - not some on 3par and some on swift
 > backed by disks all over storage nodes.
 > 
 > The reality is the architecture you describe would never be
 > deployed in the field because of a variety of concerns, risk being
 > most visible.  This is why glance's strategy of "ignoring" file
 > backed storage is a non-starter in the minds of operators.
 > 
 > Further Kolla operators don't typically agree with the argument you
 > have made (use two types of storage for the same OpenStack).  This
 > is one reason OpenStack has a reputation as a disjointed set of
 > things rather then one clean-cut architecture.
 > 
 > Regards
 > -steve

Thanks, this explains a lot! I haven't realized that you want to use Glance file backed to utilize 3PAR as its store. I believe this use case should be implemented in an alternative way. There should either be a 3PAR Glance backend plugin that can handle multiple glance-apis utilizing object store of a 3PAR cluster, or Glance file backend should be able to handle multiple glance-apis accessing same filesystem to provide HA.

If we're trying to solve architecture issues here, then I'm strongly against addressing them through introducing more poor designs. And having multiple glance-apis that you need to iterate through to find a particular image is exactly an example of poor design.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2016-07-31 12:28:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

 > > > excuse
 > > > > my ignorance, but its my understanding that a whole lot of
 > > third
 > > > > party cinder drivers use iSCSI to integrate with Cinder.  I
 > > know
 > > > > for example that 3par + Kolla + HA is a non-starter - this
 > was
 > > > > after the company spent a whole lot of money on 3par gear.
 > > > >
 > > > > If an individual uses iSCSI to integrate Cinder with their
 > > legacy
 > > > > storage systems, they are essentially cut out of being able
 > to
 > > > > operate with glance until this change merges.  I don't know
 > how
 > > > > many iSCSI integrations there are, but I'd think atleast 3par
 > > > would
 > > > > care.
 > > > >
 > > > > Hope the context helps why we need this change.
 > > >
 > > > But what prevents you from running Swift cluster as a Glance
 > > store
 > > > and use 3PAR as Cinder backend? I don't understand how iSCSI
 > > Cinder
 > > > driver means a necessity to run multiple glance-api with file
 > > > backends. Can you elaborate more on that?
 > >
 > > Your right in that you could configure CEPH or some other
 > > distributed store with Glance, but if you were to do that, why
 > > bother with hardware storage gear only for Cinder in the first
 > > place?
 > >
 > > The fundamental requirement I see is folks buy storage gear -
 > they
 > > want ALL storage on that gear - not some on 3par and some on
 > swift
 > > backed by disks all over storage nodes.
 > >
 > > The reality is the architecture you describe would never be
 > > deployed in the field because of a variety of concerns, risk
 > being
 > > most visible.  This is why glance's strategy of "ignoring" file
 > > backed storage is a non-starter in the minds of operators.
 > >
 > > Further Kolla operators don't typically agree with the argument
 > you
 > > have made (use two types of storage for the same OpenStack). 
 > This
 > > is one reason OpenStack has a reputation as a disjointed set of
 > > things rather then one clean-cut architecture.
 > >
 > > Regards
 > > -steve
 > 
 > Thanks, this explains a lot! I haven't realized that you want to
 > use Glance file backed to utilize 3PAR as its store. I believe this
 > use case should be implemented in an alternative way. There should
 > either be a 3PAR Glance backend plugin that can handle multiple
 > glance-apis utilizing object store of a 3PAR cluster, or Glance
 > file backend should be able to handle multiple glance-apis
 > accessing same filesystem to provide HA.
 > 
 > If we're trying to solve architecture issues here, then I'm
 > strongly against addressing them through introducing more poor
 > designs. And having multiple glance-apis that you need to iterate
 > through to find a particular image is exactly an example of poor
 > design.

Is 3par the only scenario where this occurs?  My understanding (limited as it is, as I have already explained) is that many hardware storage systems use iscsi as a backend.

I agree the entire design and philosophy of glance is the root of the problem here - but the "poor design" is already implemented in nova, glance, and cinder.  Its not like we are adding to the problem - we are only using what is available and published in the documentation.

FWIW this code is buggy as is prior to this patch, and this code only fixes the defect.  I think architectural problems should be considered in a different patch and different set of work.

To be clear the defect is that Cinder returns None (which is an API contract violation) if no image is found.  The intent of the code is to iterate over all glance APIs.  Whether that intent is correct or not is what your debating.  Viewing the code, the intent seems clear, even though you may find it architecturally unclean (fwiw I agree, its imperfect, as is much code in OpenStack).

As far as I can tell, this patch needs no further work - hence a -1 vote doesn't make sense to me.  A vote of -2 or a vote of +2 seem like the only reasonable choices.

Regards,
-steve'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2016-07-31 14:28:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

After reading the bug I have to say that I agree with Steven that this bug is still valid and it should be fixed, but I'm totally opposed to fix this by adding a retry mechanism in Cinder and Nova, this should be done by the python-glanceclient project, which should accept multiple server addresses and automatically retry as necessary by their terrible design choices.

Cinder and Nova should only have to pass the server addresses and wait for a final response."}, {'account_id': 26355, 'date': '2018-06-30 15:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-04-16 18:52:11.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2016-04-16 15:27:05.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Retry when glance returns None

retry logic in cinder when glance returns None so a later access
of the call function doen't reference a variable with None.  This

a bit and just use a generic call wrapper and pass in the method
and issue the command to the image service using getattr.

Frankly, this might not be such a hot idea, the initial fix
proposed by sdake is good fro handling fetch related calls,
however there are a few methods we call here that return None
as an expected result.

For now, we'll add a list of expected None result methods to
the glance.call check and that should solve the HA issues
reported by the Kolla team.

commit_message:
Retry when glance returns None on fetch

Glance will return None if the image is not found.  Trigger the
retry logic in cinder when glance returns None so a later access
of the call function doesn't reference a variable with None.  This
can result in a stack backtrace in the download function because
the result of call is used as an iterable.

NOTE: The fix here isn't the cleanest, because we sort of cheat
a bit and just use a generic call wrapper and pass in the method
and issue the command to the image service using getattr.

Frankly, this might not be such a hot idea, the initial fix
proposed by sdake is good fro handling fetch related calls,
however there are a few methods we call here that return None
as an expected result.

For now, we'll add a list of expected None result methods to
the glance.call check and that should solve the HA issues
reported by the Kolla team.

Co-Authored-By: John Griffith <john.griffith8@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I975825eeba8129cd9041d7ec3401d995a7870a12
Closes-Bug: #1571211

commit_message:
debian: add ci and update meta

This patch adds the Debian jobs for this role to make sure
it's always passing as well as updates the meta to reflect
it's support of Debian accordingly.

Depends-On: I9a92b73c419a0dc1cca40dacfef75de61a61db94
Change-Id: I626c183c0ecffdb731f87722c840121f7dfd6aae
(cherry picked from commit 6312c1cc7ef1d7a1b6dd0d6db67f3e05d1416b96)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-22 00:44:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ZFSSANFS driver accepts wrong value

ZFSSANFS driver max_over_subscription_ratio currently checks if ratio is
greater than 0 however, the lowest ratio this value could be is 1. A
ratio of 1.0 means provisioned capacity cannot exceed the total
capacity.

Change-Id: Ibd3ef085dd725dd4036170273a645d5b638b0269
Closes-Bug: #1746214
Signed-off-by: Kien Ha <kienha9922@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ZFSSANFS driver accepts wrong value

ZFSSANFS driver max_over_subscription_ratio currently checks if ratio is
greater than 0 however, the lowest ratio this value could be is 1. A
ratio of 1.0 means provisioned capacity cannot exceed the total
capacity.

Change-Id: Ibd3ef085dd725dd4036170273a645d5b638b0269
Closes-Bug: #1746214
Signed-off-by: Kien Ha <kienha9922@gmail.com>

So maybe a new tarball is not needed.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-04-16 14:21:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-04-16 14:23:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
[sahara] final releases for pike

This is a procedural review to tag a final release for each deliverables ; and

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Iff3391df2b0edd33e931770270d05b9f673bfe4d

commit_message:
[oslo] final releases for pike

This is a procedural review to tag a final release for each deliverables ; and

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Ifcb051db33bffbfe7c183b726e7c54c310c488e1

commit_message:
opensuse: move suse jobs to non-voting

The jobs have been broken for weeks now, let's move it to non-voting
to give a chance to the openSUSE team to fix it.

Change-Id: Id887f46d25c60ff1dda2a69fdc9216617f85187f

Missing print format will cause 'ValueError: unsupported
format character' error, this is to fix it.

subject: Force refresh instance info_cache during heal
messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:22:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This should not be backported, using this only to get a clean cherry-pick.  This will be useful for anyone who is looking to run this against a cloud that has been running with enough virtual_interface records, you can check it using:

SELECT instances.uuid, COUNT(virtual_interfaces.uuid) FROM instances LEFT JOIN virtual_interfaces ON virtual_interfaces.instance_uuid = instances.uuid WHERE instances.deleted=0 GROUP BY instances.uuid;'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-16 16:21:23.000000000', 'message': 'Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923
(cherry picked from commit ba44c155ce1dcefede9741722a0525820d6da2b8)
'}]
commit_message:
Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923
(cherry picked from commit ba44c155ce1dcefede9741722a0525820d6da2b8)

commit_message:
[swift] final releases for pike

This is a procedural review to tag a final release for each deliverables ; and

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Iefee6ab04e297fe52e4e8eae77e7bf7889ca8763

commit_message:
Tiller: Add pod/container security context

This updates the tiller chart to include the pod
security context on the pod template

This also adds the container security context to set
allowPrivilegeEscalation to false

Change-Id: Ic0d87ba2e933444ebe8a6d59d7bb74aae81a051d

    The README was overall clean and clear, however there were some areas of improvement, as well as some typos which could lead to confusion. Most are trivial changes.

    Terminate sentence with period to match rest of list

    Add commas to introductory phrases to match rest of readme

    Change duplicate 'os-internal-hostname' to 'os-admin-hostname'

    Change 'https' to 'HTTPS' to match header of section

    Fix typo 'they secondary' to 'the secondary'

Change-Id: I38483df4340849cd268c74183b44eaf6bc02b238
"}, {'created': '2019-04-12 19:09:25.000000000', 'message': "Fix  grammatical errors, some  typos, and general inconsistencies

    The README was overall clean and clear, however there were some
    areas of improvement, as well as some typos which could lead to
    confusion. Most are trivial changes.

    - Terminate sentence with period to match rest of list
    - Add commas to introductory phrases to match rest of readme
    - Change duplicate 'os-internal-hostname' to 'os-admin-hostname'
    - Change 'https' to 'HTTPS' to match header of section
    - Fix typo 'they secondary' to 'the secondary'
    - Remove comma from 'unit, and must' as is not a compound sentence
    - Change 'Note' to 'NOTE' to match rest of readme
    - Capitalized first word in NOTE section to match rest of readme

Change-Id: I38483df4340849cd268c74183b44eaf6bc02b238

commit_message:
Fix  grammatical errors, some  typos, and general inconsistencies

    The README was overall clean and clear, however there were some
    areas of improvement, as well as some typos which could lead to
    confusion. Most are trivial changes.

    - Terminate sentence with period to match rest of list
    - Add commas to introductory phrases to match rest of readme
    - Change duplicate 'os-internal-hostname' to 'os-admin-hostname'
    - Change 'https' to 'HTTPS' to match header of section
    - Fix typo 'they secondary' to 'the secondary'
    - Remove comma from 'unit, and must' as is not a compound sentence
    - Change 'Note' to 'NOTE' to match rest of readme
    - Capitalized first word in NOTE section to match rest of readme

Change-Id: I38483df4340849cd268c74183b44eaf6bc02b238

'}]
commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I10ac5a633a2549e8053b5f0f438f692b5efca821

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-14 21:38:13.000000000', 'message': "debian: add ci and update meta

This patch adds the Debian jobs for this role to make sure
it's always passing as well as updates the meta to reflect
it's support of Debian accordingly.

It also clean-up an old variable which is carried for upgrades
that is no longer relevant now.

A new variable has been added to ensure pre-packages, which
have been generally assumed to be installed as a base OS
package, have been installed before installing the application
or configuring the system via the role.

Depends-On: I135ea73604890eae5e9e2a7cdcab81b2b39ad426
Change-Id: I19094b540aff81b7aa029880e404a2990f82e538
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>
(cherry picked from commit b3c79f944b4839674bb1d1a457a0438a5b725c3b)
"}]
commit_message:
debian: add ci and update meta

This patch adds the Debian jobs for this role to make sure
it's always passing as well as updates the meta to reflect
it's support of Debian accordingly.

It also clean-up an old variable which is carried for upgrades
that is no longer relevant now.

A new variable has been added to ensure pre-packages, which
have been generally assumed to be installed as a base OS
package, have been installed before installing the application
or configuring the system via the role.

Depends-On: I135ea73604890eae5e9e2a7cdcab81b2b39ad426
Change-Id: I19094b540aff81b7aa029880e404a2990f82e538
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>
(cherry picked from commit b3c79f944b4839674bb1d1a457a0438a5b725c3b)

commit_message:
Fixed wrong cinder store user name

The value for 'cinder_store_user_name' should be only user name
instead of tenant:username

Changing value of 'cinder_store_user_name' to 'glance' from
'service:glance'

Closes-Bug: #1809104
Change-Id: Idbc3541564fb405d60cf3dcc01960fd5e0befb97
(cherry picked from commit
1efe2a018a409d7d6a50a1a5d6155c72a08bfa73)

commit_message:
Ensure LBaaS SG update upon allow from everywhere NP is enforced

The LBaaS Security group is not updated when a Network Policy
that allows traffic from everywhere is enforced.
This commit fixes the issue by removing the restriction that rules
without 'remote_ip_prefix' are not taken into account when applying
the members sg rules.

Change-Id: Id23934bc701ddda33cbbd87f4fc184fb682005c1
Closes-Bug: 1823922

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-16 03:05:38.000000000', 'message': "Set Standalone's br-ctlplane MTU

Set the br-ctlplane MTU to the InterfaceLocalMtu value. This is
required when multiple Standalone nodes are used in a split-stack
deployment.

Closes-Bug: #1823993
Change-Id: I84a35d529ee67e939db1cdadd103f88295e41e8f
(cherry picked from commit 00b56e07bf8e9f36faa424c067058584b40e3904)
"}]
commit_message:
Set Standalone's br-ctlplane MTU

Set the br-ctlplane MTU to the InterfaceLocalMtu value. This is
required when multiple Standalone nodes are used in a split-stack
deployment.

Closes-Bug: #1823993
Change-Id: I84a35d529ee67e939db1cdadd103f88295e41e8f
(cherry picked from commit 00b56e07bf8e9f36faa424c067058584b40e3904)

Force the use of odl xenial repo on bionic

There is no repo for bionic currently so force the use of the xenial
repo.

commit_message:
Repropose unfinished Stein specs to Train

The explicit domain IDs and capabilities/access rules specs were not
finished in Stein but are already in progress and on target to finish
early in the Train cycle.

Change-Id: I052079fcdb11f8e11c854b11d8013fd460f421ec

commit_message:
Allow deployment of Undercloud (VM) without direct access to the underlying virthost.

This commit adds a playbook (based on baremetal-undercloud) calling
a generic baremetal provisioning script to deploy a Undercloud VM.
Such script should return when the Undercloud VM is accessible via ssh.
Afterwards the playbook resumes the expected workflow of inventory generation,
repositories setup etc.

Change-Id: Iea00c2a54e10d725b2ab9ee6ce5d71c64a460c02

commit_message:
Make pytest run generate html reports

Improve readability of pytest executions by producing html reports
which are also advertised by zuul, saving user time.

Change-Id: I306ad28c855c59f3d575da7a6132782ce02966d7

subject: Retrigger tagging ocata-em for timed out repos
messages: [{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-04-15 18:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-04-16 02:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThanks'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-04-16 16:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-15 18:31:25.000000000', 'message': 'Retrigger tagging ocata-em for timed out repos

During the tag-releases job for the "Tag stable/ocata as extended
maintenance" patch d57f810ad6555528a4af039b693453b551da4cf2, the job
timed out processing all affected repos. There were just a few that need
to have the job run again to push up the tag. This makes a noop change
in those repos to get the tagging to complete.

Change-Id: Iae06ecaca1059bf761d21b91eb5b7e5dd5d2519a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Retrigger tagging ocata-em for timed out repos

During the tag-releases job for the "Tag stable/ocata as extended
maintenance" patch d57f810ad6555528a4af039b693453b551da4cf2, the job
timed out processing all affected repos. There were just a few that need
to have the job run again to push up the tag. This makes a noop change
in those repos to get the tagging to complete.

Change-Id: Iae06ecaca1059bf761d21b91eb5b7e5dd5d2519a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Retrigger manila-ui 2.13.1 tagging

Job definition errors caused the tag-release job to fail to run for this
release. This makes a trivial modification to the deliverable file so
that the change can be merged to trigger tagging to happen again.

Change-Id: I69188b61977aac5ff2d296868baf8e498a61afb9
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-22815 : SUCCESS in 1h 04m 04s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-08-16 08:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/591607/3 : FAILURE in 2h 12m 17s'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2018-08-27 07:42:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Looks good to me, thank you!'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-09-04 15:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-14 16:44:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

During the PTG the question was asked, why don't we just do a full refresh on a network-changed event? Today we have the same issue with network-changed (if a port ID isn't part of the event) - we only refresh the ports already in the cache. In the cases I've seen in this bug, the problem is out of band stuff happening in neutron (like policy file changes) that change what gets returned to nova, so in those cases I'm not even sure nova gets a network-changed event (in case we wanted to force a full refresh in that case)."}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-09-17 14:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

PTG Question is legit. There is a command in novaclient, which produces a network-changed event: nova refresh-network. In case of the corrupted instance info_cache what is expected by operators after running this command is to force refresh info_cache from the neutron.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 16:51:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> PTG Question is legit. There is a command in novaclient, which produces a network-changed event: nova refresh-network. In case of the corrupted instance info_cache what is expected by operators after running this command is to force refresh info_cache from the neutron.

Huh, I wasn't even aware of https://docs.openstack.org/python-novaclient/latest/cli/nova.html#nova-refresh-network."}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2018-09-17 19:54:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > PTG Question is legit. There is a command in novaclient, which
 > produces a network-changed event: nova refresh-network. In case of
 > the corrupted instance info_cache what is expected by operators
 > after running this command is to force refresh info_cache from the
 > neutron.
 > 
 > Huh, I wasn't even aware of https://docs.openstack.org/python-novaclient/latest/cli/nova.html#nova-refresh-network.

Yeah we hijacked this to force a network info_cache refresh. I assumed this was what it did until I read the code"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 20:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

OK so would operators prefer to have the network-changed event do the full refresh (if a specific port isn't provided) or have the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic do the full refresh? I could see an argument that having the operator force it on-demand would be better to avoid all the nova<>neutron API traffic during the periodic if nothing actually changed, but on the other hand having the heal task do it makes it "just work".'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-17 20:10:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

FWIW, the reason the refresh from the network-changed event probably never refreshed the full list of ports from neutron is likely due to the heavy traffic load it would cause during migrations where we used to get and process a redundant network-changed event per port attached to the server during the migration. Change I023b5b1ccb248e68189f62ba0ff75d41093c1f60 optimized that flow so we only refresh on the single port if neutron gives us one.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-09-18 13:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

That nova cli command was a XenAPI special where the networking info is re-injected inside the guest, using the xenapi guest agent, if present.

I think this is what people expect to happen, refresh the ports, so it seems sensible to me. Not +W given the active discussions.'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2018-09-19 22:30:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

> OK so would operators prefer to have the network-changed event do
 > the full refresh (if a specific port isn't provided) or have the
 > _heal_instance_info_cache periodic do the full refresh? I could see
 > an argument that having the operator force it on-demand would be
 > better to avoid all the nova<>neutron API traffic during the
 > periodic if nothing actually changed, but on the other hand having
 > the heal task do it makes it "just work".

Yeah tricky question, I can see an argument for either. In large clouds it might not be a good idea to have the periodic run (or at least not often). Having a manual switch is always very handy.'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-09-20 10:11:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I just remembered one case, in which this patch could lead to a major regression and huge fault in some deployments.

If I remember correctly, nova takes information about instances ports during hard reboot from the info_caches. And vifs order (net0, net1 in libvirt xml) depends on the vifs order in info_caches. If we refresh info_caches from neutron on every _heal_instance_info_cache periodic tasks, it could end up with interfaces being in the different order then it was before healing.

For example, let's take an instance that was created with shared vlan network port (shared_network_port) as eth0 (net0) and then another port from the private local vxlan network (local_network_port) was attached to this instance as eth1 (net1). This interface order will be constant across instance reboots and after other operations. After refresh this ports might be written into the info_caches in a different order (shared_network_port as eth1 and local_network_port as eth0). This will break vms network connectivity after hard reboot if there is no dhcp in this network or if interfaces are set up statically in /etc/network/interfaces"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-11 22:19:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Vlad, nic (and block device) order is never guaranteed as far as I know, and that's why we have virtual device tags for nics and volumes so the user can tag their devices and from within the guest know which is which and order appropriately."}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2018-10-12 01:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-10-12 01:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I believe nic ordering was always expected to be consistent. This patchset might become the year 2018 version of the bug from 2012 (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1064524 ) or 2014 (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1300325 ).
Tags can only be exposed to the guest via config drive or metadata, and both of them are not mandatory. Users can choose not to use cloud-init at all after first boot and just use static network config then. Even if nova will expose tags to the nics, all previously created instances will not have an ability to reconfigure network interfaces based on new tags.
It will be a disaster for any operator, who provides an ability to use multiple nics for instances. Just imagine all nics in instance_info_cache being mixed up after several minutes after Stein update, and result of this mess will show up only after instances hard reboot. What should the operator do? Ask all his customers to understand, that now network interfaces might be shuffled and their order are not persistent or ask them to recreate instances from the new image?'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-10-12 01:52:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Some distros don't even have cloud-init, which could be updated to read tags from metadata/config drive.
For example, Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Virtual for KVM expects consistent NIC order: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/quick_start/kvm/ftdv-kvm-qsg.html#pgfId-3318479
Other NFV distros, like Juniper vSRX, or even OpenStack Octaiva Amphoraes images probably too."}, {'account_id': 27442, 'date': '2018-10-19 14:17:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2018-10-24 12:51:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I just remembered one case, in which this patch could lead to a
 > major regression and huge fault in some deployments.
 > 
 > If I remember correctly, nova takes information about instances
 > ports during hard reboot from the info_caches. And vifs order
 > (net0, net1 in libvirt xml) depends on the vifs order in
 > info_caches. If we refresh info_caches from neutron on every
 > _heal_instance_info_cache periodic tasks, it could end up with
 > interfaces being in the different order then it was before healing.
 > 
 > For example, let's take an instance that was created with shared
 > vlan network port (shared_network_port) as eth0 (net0) and then
 > another port from the private local vxlan network (local_network_port)
 > was attached to this instance as eth1 (net1). This interface order
 > will be constant across instance reboots and after other
 > operations. After refresh this ports might be written into the
 > info_caches in a different order (shared_network_port as eth1 and
 > local_network_port as eth0). This will break vms network
 > connectivity after hard reboot if there is no dhcp in this network
 > or if interfaces are set up statically in /etc/network/interfaces

So I have found solution to rebuild the instance_info_caches with proper interfaces order.
We have table called nova.virtual_interfaces.

Consider example:
select * from virtual_interfaces where instance_uuid='dd3edcfa-2ff8-4cdc-ac86-90644fd0bf3d';
+---------------------+------------+------------+-----+--------------------------------------------------------+------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+------+
| created_at          | updated_at | deleted_at | id  | address                                                | network_id | uuid                                 | instance_uuid                        | deleted | tag  |
+---------------------+------------+------------+-----+--------------------------------------------------------+------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+------+
| 2018-10-24 11:05:19 | NULL       | NULL       | 119 | fa:16:3e:b7:dc:d9/2590aecc-65cd-46eb-8834-e01d61ad06d2 |       NULL | 2590aecc-65cd-46eb-8834-e01d61ad06d2 | dd3edcfa-2ff8-4cdc-ac86-90644fd0bf3d |       0 | NULL |
| 2018-10-24 11:16:49 | NULL       | NULL       | 121 | fa:16:3e:1a:06:25/a87bfa46-31c3-435b-9109-82d382a9a604 |       NULL | a87bfa46-31c3-435b-9109-82d382a9a604 | dd3edcfa-2ff8-4cdc-ac86-90644fd0bf3d |       0 | NULL |
| 2018-10-24 11:17:27 | NULL       | NULL       | 123 | fa:16:3e:1b:9b:02/61a36ab8-a4a8-495b-ad1b-2c200f0fecd7 |       NULL | 61a36ab8-a4a8-495b-ad1b-2c200f0fecd7 | dd3edcfa-2ff8-4cdc-ac86-90644fd0bf3d |       0 | NULL |

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-14 10:02:17.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923
'}, {'created': '2018-08-15 03:48:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task

Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461

'}, {'created': '2018-08-16 06:40:19.000000000', 'message': 'Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923

'}, {'created': '2018-10-30 10:39:35.000000000', 'message': 'Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id

is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for

objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces

attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923
'}, {'created': '2018-12-21 08:18:27.000000000', 'message': 'Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923

commit_message:
Force refresh instance info_cache during heal

If the instance info_cache is corrupted somehow, like during
a host reboot and the ports aren't wired up properly or
a mistaken policy change in neutron results in nova resetting
the info_cache to an empty list, the _heal_instance_info_cache
is meant to fix it (once the current state of the ports for
the instance in neutron is corrected). However, the task is
currently only refreshing the cache *based* on the current contents
of the cache, which defeats the purpose of neutron being the source
of truth for the ports attached to the instance.

This change makes the _heal_instance_info_cache periodic task
pass a "force_refresh" kwarg, which defaults to False for backward
compatibility with other methods that refresh the cache after
operations like attach/detach interface, and if True will make
nova get the current state of the ports for the instance from neutron
and fully rebuild the info_cache.

To not lose port order in info_cache this change takes original order
from nova historical data that are stored as VirtualInterfaceList
objects. For ports that are not registered as VirtualInterfaces
objects it will add them at the end of port_order list. Due to this
for instances older than Newton another patch was introduced to fill
missing VirtualInterface objects in the DB [1].

Long-term we should be able to refactor some of the older refresh
code which leverages the cache to instead use the refresh_vif_id
kwarg so that we do targeted cache updates when we do things like
attach and detach ports, but that's a change for another day.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614167

Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jozefczyk <maciej.jozefczyk@corp.ovh.com>
Change-Id: I629415236b2447128ae9a980d4ebe730a082c461
Closes-Bug: #1751923

subject: Place upper bound on python-dracclient version

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651657/ . It will be backported to

Change-Id: I5f6d6be53aec9d72e8ba5cfa436f12e01966f871
"}]
commit_message:
Place upper bound on python-dracclient version

The idrac hardware type requires python-dracclient versions greater than
or equal to 1.5.0 and less than 3.0.0.

This defines the upper bound to be less than 3.0.0 to make it easier to
backport to stable/stein. It was originally proposed against
stable/stein -- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645956/ . Reviewers
asked that it be submitted against master first --
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645956/1/driver-requirements.txt@12 --
and then backported to stable/stein.

The ironic master and stable/stein branches are compatible with
python-dracclient releases less than 3.0.0. Note that
python-dracclient's stable/stein branch was created off of tag 2.0.0.
The ironic stable/stein branch follows tag 12.1.0, which was created on
March 21. The python-dracclient tag 3.0.0 was created after that, on
April 4. The upper bound on master will be updated to less than 4.0.0 by
a follow-on change.

A related change has been proposed for stable/rocky --
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651657/ . It will be backported to
stable/queens and prior after it merges.

Change-Id: I5f6d6be53aec9d72e8ba5cfa436f12e01966f871

commit_message:
libvirt: disconnect volume when encryption fails

The compute node has left the attachment information after the
encryption fails. This patch fixes this by ensuring the volume is
disconnected when an exception occurs.

Change-Id: I9d652f182d83a2557ff6ed0b21c69a735c3f9840
Closes-Bug: #1812945
(cherry picked from commit 79bcb4e21b7909f3e989d4fbcf68ac268680b865)
(cherry picked from commit d773e3b1469a76f129d2f7a4edab68d007f3f928)

[{'created': '2019-03-19 14:05:34.000000000', 'message': "Add container_cli used for the Overcloud to the Inventory

Some validations run commands on multiple containers and have to know if
the Overcloud has been deployed using Docker or Podman.

This patch gets the information from the Overcloud stack environment
and adds 'container_cli' as Overcloud vars.

Change-Id: I7541bfd244acaf1d00d18b3eef031dbadfe4dd4a
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add container_cli used for the Overcloud to the Inventory

Some validations run commands on multiple containers and have to know if
the Overcloud has been deployed using Docker or Podman.

This patch gets the 'ContainerCli' variable from the Overcloud stack
environment and adds it as an Overcloud vars.

Change-Id: I7541bfd244acaf1d00d18b3eef031dbadfe4dd4a
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Prevent bind fip to port has port forwarding

If one port has port forwarding and the port is under
a dvr router, then binding floating IP to this port
will not be allowed.

Change-Id: Ia014e18264b43cf751a5bc0e82bc55d106582620
Closes-Bug: #1799138
(cherry picked from commit 433228dd78098ca84a13c75b9dc5ce40f43c7f9d)

commit_message:
Make test service_plugins override simple

Just make things simple and give a chance to accept that
ordered 'service_plugins' list or tuple for the base test
class NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase.

Change-Id: I7c352ede811703e3a96848378b92cbbf5e109228
Related-Bug: #1809238
(cherry picked from commit 76c28812013c558041612609efe30b88a5226267)

Add minimum value in max_concurrent_live_migrations

Add minimum value 0 in the max_concurrent_live_migrations option.

Change-Id: I52ead0154e311a0ebdfd6d7413704fa350020587

commit_message:
devstack: Remove syslinux dependency

syslinux should no longer be required by any arch. This patch removes
the dependency.

Change-Id: Id4aea9acb9bf4ac34c0d5e9bca27fb48ea1b009a

Ironic python agent does not extract correct available memory

This patch fixes parsing of memory class output of lshw output.
Task: 30201
Story: 2005308

Change-Id: I0e7ff9f86a266d2f798457136fed0100c78569e2

commit_message:
Implement ResetConfig and ClearForeignConfig functionality

For raid deletion, existing delete_virtual_disk functionality is not
freeing up foreign drives and spares, so have added ResetConfig and
ClearForeignConfig functionality for freeing up foreign drives and
spares.

Change-Id: I76390dc4fcf8de2fe5aa3d660f77edcef4a4dec1

commit_message:
Don't warn on network-vif-unplugged event during live migration

The "network-vif-unplugged" event is expected during live migration
and nothing listens for it so we should not log a warning in that case.

Change-Id: I8fd8df211670f1abbcb7b496e62589295922bdc1
Closes-Bug: #1819764
(cherry picked from commit 521e59224e8a595af66ec898f1bb739a9dbe7d97)
(cherry picked from commit 17e6ca727207a21028f2878a1e01047c1be2ad36)

it's support of Debian accordingly.

commit_message:
Support python 3.6 and 3.7

Python 2.7, Python 3.7 and Python 3.6 runtimes.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I41aff6a8dc52d4038431ce7566ff8177e25cea6b

(1 comment)

LGTM, I've commented on a nit in the conflict NOTE where you've called out the change above this not being present in stable/rocky that I assume was from an earlier local attempt to cherry-pick this.

I'm not going to ask for a respin as it should be pretty clear to anyone reading the commit in the future what has happened. The other conflicts LGTM to me and this has also landed in stable/stein. Again, as this is from another Nova stable core I'm going to fast approve."}]

commit_message:
Error out migration when confirm_resize fails

If anything fails and raises an exception during
confirm_resize, the migration status is stuck in
"confirming" status even though the instance status
may be "ERROR".

This change adds the errors_out_migration decorator
to the confirm_resize method to make sure the migration
status is "error" if an error is raised.

In bug 1821594 it was the driver.confirm_migration
method that raised some exception, so a unit test is
added here which simulates a similar scenario.

This only partially closes the bug because we are still
leaking allocations on the source node resource provider
since _delete_allocation_after_move is not called. That
will be dealt with in a separate patch.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(mriedem): The functional test conflict is due to not
having change I99427a52676826990d2a2ffc82cf30ad945b939c
in Rocky. The unit test conflict is due to not having
change I0851e2d54a1fdc82fe3291fb7e286e790f121e92 in Rocky.
The source_node attribute on the fake Migration object in
the unit test is added here because change
I312d61383345ea0ac1ab0c277b4c468e6aa94656 is not in Rocky.

Change-Id: Ic7d78ad43a2bad7f932c22c98944accbbed9e9e2
Partial-Bug: #1821594
(cherry picked from commit 408ef8f84a698f764aa5d769d6d01fd9340de2e5)
(cherry picked from commit 972d4e0eb391e83fe8d3020ff95db0e6a840a224)

commit_message:
Add ipBlock support to NP

This commit adds support for ipBlocks when using Network Policies with
Kuryr-Kubernetes.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-29 13:48:25.000000000', 'message': 'Temporarily mutate migration object in finish_revert_resize

As the comment in the code suggests, when calling migrate_instance_finish
in finish_revert_resize we need to temporarily set the migration
object dest_compute to the source_compute since we are moving port
bindings from the dest back to the source. However, this is not
really a temporary change to the object if something fails after
this because the @errors_out_migration decorator will persist the
change which could be confusing later if trying to debug this migration
from the API and the dest_compute and source_compute have the same value.

This fixes the issue by using the temporary_mutation utility.

Also, the obj_to_primitive dance in here is removed since it is not
necessary as migrate_instance_finish handles a Migration object.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
I0851e2d54a1fdc82fe3291fb7e286e790f121e92 in Rocky.

Change-Id: I312d61383345ea0ac1ab0c277b4c468e6aa94656
Closes-Bug: #1818730
(cherry picked from commit 855b5546564f0ed96243623b67b1322e9b891c8b)
(cherry picked from commit bcb42a43a9f12d929ec7025f29bd2e3d482cd406)
'}]
commit_message:
Temporarily mutate migration object in finish_revert_resize

As the comment in the code suggests, when calling migrate_instance_finish
in finish_revert_resize we need to temporarily set the migration
object dest_compute to the source_compute since we are moving port
bindings from the dest back to the source. However, this is not
really a temporary change to the object if something fails after
this because the @errors_out_migration decorator will persist the
change which could be confusing later if trying to debug this migration
from the API and the dest_compute and source_compute have the same value.

This fixes the issue by using the temporary_mutation utility.

Also, the obj_to_primitive dance in here is removed since it is not
necessary as migrate_instance_finish handles a Migration object.

Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to not having change
I0851e2d54a1fdc82fe3291fb7e286e790f121e92 in Rocky.

Change-Id: I312d61383345ea0ac1ab0c277b4c468e6aa94656
Closes-Bug: #1818730
(cherry picked from commit 855b5546564f0ed96243623b67b1322e9b891c8b)

[{'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-03-07 13:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16845, 'date': '2019-03-07 13:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can we use a CLiI argument to take the path of the directory to place these profiler results in?'}, {'account_id': 10267, 'date': '2019-03-08 07:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Can we use a CLiI argument to take the path of the directory to
 > place these profiler results in?

Useful suggestion, but I want to have changes only in rally-openstack and don't want to introduce changes in rally.

Stats will be dumped in pstat format which has to be converted into text format. Thinking of doing that as a seperate change (i.e enhancing "rally task report --out=report1.html --open" to generate calltrace as text file). Also need to check if I can do that by only changing rally-openstack.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-03-08 11:37:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Since `	rally_openstack/contexts/oslo_service` is a new python module, it should include __init__.py empty file, otherwise python interpreter will not find rally_openstack/contexts/oslo_service/eventlet_backdor.py'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-03-08 11:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks a lot Andrey. Now I understand why I got this error http://paste.openstack.org/show/747444

No reviews for this patch for a long time. Can someone please review it?'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-04-10 17:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

sorry for that. will get back to review tomorrow'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-04-16 14:46:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

Sorry for a long review. In general, look good to me, just several small suggestions about jsonschema and one question: 

I'm not familiar about oslo.service profiling and documentaion doesn't answer my question. Where "stats" file will be saved? at the local machine(where rally is rally executed) or at the api side?'}]

commit_message:
Capture OpenStack services inspection data

Oslo.service eventlet_backdoor allows to inspect Openstack services and
capture processes greenthreads, nativethreads, python memory objects and
python function calltrace. We enable rally to capture this data during
rally scenario runs which helps developers to debug performance issues.
In this change, we add support for profiling function calltrace.

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.service/latest/user/usage.html#profiling
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/master/oslo_service/eventlet_backdoor.py#L198
http://eventlet.net/doc/modules/backdoor.html

Change-Id: Iaa508f47579f8fea470b1d2bed73584027138eeb

here causes an error when zuul tries to load the job graph.

'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Increase tag-releases job timeout"

Parent job is currently marked final, so attempting to override setting
here causes an error when zuul tries to load the job graph.

This reverts commit cd3ac58467ac73eba4348ea6ecf4142bf019527e.

Change-Id: Idcb8f5ceadcc36af1cceace84691e505409c6ebd

commit_message:
neutron.conf needs lock_path set for router to operate
This change is adding required configuration in neutron.conf
to set the lock_path parameter, which was missing in
compute-install-ubuntu.rst

Change-Id: If090bdf060dfe21d11b1a5dfd010dc8167d9e45e
Closes-Bug: #1796976

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

commit_message:
Add list-manageable for rbd

Right now, the rbd backend does not support to list manageable
volume and snapshot. So add it.

Change-Id: I2a8c007c445992c5d95481baf22535019348e256

Provide option to disable EMC in puppet-vswitch

	deployment/neutron/neutron-ovs-agent-container-puppet.yaml

commit_message:
Change a log level for overwriting allocation

Change a log level for overwriting allocation
to debug instead of warning
because the log message is output in the normal case
of reverting resize.

Change-Id: I4f2ee3f420b4c78385eeb56c7e8c343af894e75c
Closes-Bug: #1822917

commit_message:
User guide

The review improves User Guide, it adds steps which
describe how to clone and install os_tempest. The
new doc also mentions what has to be set in a playbook
which runs os_tempest.

subject: Write hash after compressing horizon static assets
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-04-16 06:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-04-16 07:34:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2019-04-16 11:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-16 06:58:01.000000000', 'message': 'Write hash after compressing horizon static assets

If you run the horizon container with a restart policy of never, and the
static asset compression fails, the container fails to start, e.g. (seen
in CI)

++ /usr/bin/manage.py collectstatic --noinput --clear
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/manage.py", line 18, in <module>
      from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
  ImportError: No module named django.core.management

However, with a restart policy of unless-stopped (the default).  the
horizon container will fail the first time but will succeed after a
restart. This is because the settings bundle hash is updated before the
compression is attempted.

To fix this, update the hash after compression completes successfully.

Change-Id: I3f1682ed55e7d45c1e97a1b34c7993aa839f0bb2
Closes-Bug: #1824137
(cherry picked from commit 92c2456851857c45e8de9a3ff8f167579e0588f4)
'}]
commit_message:
Write hash after compressing horizon static assets

If you run the horizon container with a restart policy of never, and the
static asset compression fails, the container fails to start, e.g. (seen
in CI)

++ /usr/bin/manage.py collectstatic --noinput --clear
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/manage.py", line 18, in <module>
      from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
  ImportError: No module named django.core.management

However, with a restart policy of unless-stopped (the default).  the
horizon container will fail the first time but will succeed after a
restart. This is because the settings bundle hash is updated before the
compression is attempted.

To fix this, update the hash after compression completes successfully.

Change-Id: I3f1682ed55e7d45c1e97a1b34c7993aa839f0bb2
Closes-Bug: #1824137
(cherry picked from commit 92c2456851857c45e8de9a3ff8f167579e0588f4)

commit_message:
Fix the bond-with-vlans NIC config DPDK route indentation

This patch fixes an indentation error in the DPDK config for
the network/config/bond-with-vlans/role.role.j2.yaml NIC
config. The DPDK config had the routes at the wrong indentation
level.

The network/config/2-linux-bonds-vlans/role.role.j2.yaml contains
a typo in the ControlPlane interface. Instead of
ControlPlaneStaticRoutes, the template contains ControlPlaneRoutes,
which doesn't exist. This patch fixes the get_param.

Change-Id: I331a06339611d423433bea243b10e4c0df8800a3
"}]
commit_message:
Fix typo in 2-linux-bonds-vlans NIC config templates

The network/config/2-linux-bonds-vlans/role.role.j2.yaml contains
a typo in the ControlPlane interface. Instead of
ControlPlaneStaticRoutes, the template contains ControlPlaneRoutes,
which doesn't exist. This patch fixes the get_param.

Change-Id: I331a06339611d423433bea243b10e4c0df8800a3

[{'created': '2019-04-16 07:56:29.000000000', 'message': 'Remove usage of oslosphinx

Seems like some recent update of Sphinx broke oslosphinx extension. We
don't really need it now, so this commit removes it by adopting the
"modern" way of building docs (mostly based on how it's done in
openstack/kuryr-kubernetes).

Change-Id: I8a0d5e3923b6497eb7c6944fc6d9adc9007bf5ec
Closes-Bug: 1824958
'}]
commit_message:
Remove usage of oslosphinx

Seems like some recent update of Sphinx broke oslosphinx extension. We
don't really need it now, so this commit removes it by adopting the
"modern" way of building docs (mostly based on how it's done in
openstack/kuryr-kubernetes).

Change-Id: I8a0d5e3923b6497eb7c6944fc6d9adc9007bf5ec
Closes-Bug: 1824958

commit_message:
Fix module imports

The patch fixes module imports in a way they comply with the OpenStack
Coding Guidelines [1], that is:
section 1: standard library modules
section 2: 3rd party modules
section 3: networking_ovn modules

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html#imports

Change-Id: Ie48e15c08755619cc278e25cfd211d0d7998138a

messages: [{'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-04-15 09:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-04-15 15:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14885, 'date': '2019-04-16 09:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-15 09:18:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix conflict exceptions handling in LB creation

I0a2f89007994fbd7696b0f487affc1b7b643be74 is breaking our workaround for
IP conflict when Kuryr-Controller dies during some LB processing. In
that case, when LB is already created, Kuryr will try to create it again
and fail with either 409 or 500. We should react to those exceptions and
aforementioned patch breaks that by changing the type of exceptions
being raised.

This patch fixes that by adding correct requests.HTTPError exception
type to that try-except clause.

Change-Id: Ic41fe6d5556b2b4721871f9812ddc039a52cf366
Closes-Bug: 1823701
(cherry picked from commit 2a9f5fdcc2f20c1be2b0cfb68c44a3386c407393)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix conflict exceptions handling in LB creation

I0a2f89007994fbd7696b0f487affc1b7b643be74 is breaking our workaround for
IP conflict when Kuryr-Controller dies during some LB processing. In
that case, when LB is already created, Kuryr will try to create it again
and fail with either 409 or 500. We should react to those exceptions and
aforementioned patch breaks that by changing the type of exceptions
being raised.

This patch fixes that by adding correct requests.HTTPError exception
type to that try-except clause.

Change-Id: Ic41fe6d5556b2b4721871f9812ddc039a52cf366
Closes-Bug: 1823701
(cherry picked from commit 2a9f5fdcc2f20c1be2b0cfb68c44a3386c407393)

commit_message:
Pin coredns container image to 1.4.0 tag

coredns 1.5.0 got released recently and removed the proxy plugin which
we use, resulting in coredns being broken. Let's just pin the container
image tag to 1.4.0, as we don't want to fix our config each time coredns
is updated. We can move it forward consciously once there's some feature
we want.

Change-Id: I9099b13b4530049d0218e7165e8e85d14a459f5e
Closes-Bug: 1823855
(cherry picked from commit 559b78532c4ab5f918a4c3632715626251b076be)
