revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-24 20:44:17.000000000', 'message': "eventletutils: Optimise EventletEvent.clear()

When EventletEvent.clear() is called twice in succession without an
intervening set(), there's no need to replace the underlying
eventlet.event.Event object, since it has never been sent. Doing so
would have woken other greenthreads waiting on the event to no
particular end.

When clear() is called after the event has been set(), we already did
not do anything special with the existing eventlet.event.Event as we
cannot call send() on it twice. We simply replace it with a new one; the
code in wait() will handle the situation correctly, since it will wake
up (due to the initial event having been sent) and begin waiting on the
new eventlet.event.Event instead. This is consistent with the observed
behaviour of threading.Event.

Change-Id: Ibd5324926431fc760c3dd0be064324e3009cc2c2
"}, {'created': '2019-01-24 21:02:18.000000000', 'message': "eventletutils: Optimise EventletEvent.clear()

When EventletEvent.clear() is called twice in succession without an
intervening set(), there's no need to replace the underlying
eventlet.event.Event object, since it has never been sent. Doing so
would have woken other greenthreads waiting on the event to no
particular end.

When clear() is called after the event has been set(), we already did
not do anything special with the existing eventlet.event.Event as we
cannot call send() on it twice. We simply replace it with a new one; the
code in wait() will handle the situation correctly, since it will wake
up (due to the initial event having been sent) and begin waiting on the
new eventlet.event.Event instead. This is consistent with the observed
behaviour of threading.Event. A new unit test verifies this.

Change-Id: Ibd5324926431fc760c3dd0be064324e3009cc2c2
"}, {'created': '2019-01-25 01:57:51.000000000', 'message': "eventletutils: Optimise EventletEvent.clear()

When EventletEvent.clear() is called twice in succession without an
intervening set(), there's no need to replace the underlying
eventlet.event.Event object, since it has never been sent. Doing so
would have woken other greenthreads waiting on the event to no
particular end.

When clear() is called after the event has been set(), we already did
not do anything special with the existing eventlet.event.Event as we
cannot call send() on it twice. We simply replace it with a new one; the
code in wait() will handle the situation correctly, since it will wake
up (due to the initial event having been sent) and begin waiting on the
new eventlet.event.Event instead. This is consistent with the observed
behaviour of threading.Event. A new unit test verifies this.

Change-Id: Ibd5324926431fc760c3dd0be064324e3009cc2c2
"}]
commit_message:
eventletutils: Optimise EventletEvent.clear()

When EventletEvent.clear() is called twice in succession without an
intervening set(), there's no need to replace the underlying
eventlet.event.Event object, since it has never been sent. Doing so
would have woken other greenthreads waiting on the event to no
particular end.

When clear() is called after the event has been set(), we already did
not do anything special with the existing eventlet.event.Event as we
cannot call send() on it twice. We simply replace it with a new one; the
code in wait() will handle the situation correctly, since it will wake
up (due to the initial event having been sent) and begin waiting on the
new eventlet.event.Event instead. This is consistent with the observed
behaviour of threading.Event. A new unit test verifies this.

Change-Id: Ibd5324926431fc760c3dd0be064324e3009cc2c2

commit_message:
Fix get_base_url

get_base_url method makes assumptions on how the
base URL should look like and trims it up to the
host IP. This change modifies how the base endpoint
is processed so we get the correct values.

Change-Id: Ie01b02f2e731e25fd4032436d3fa106da03af242
Closes-Bug: #1814094
(cherry picked from commit cb1ac1ad910efcd716c2e785699c44179fb1a8cf)

Python 2.7, Python 3.7 and Python 3.6 runtimes.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I3548290d55fda3a1192fcefb3019c35f60d5b751

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit drops python 3.5 and adds python 3.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I69b11066e334adfddb4ddc8ca2cafc6437d4457d

[DNM] test tripleo-repos role with molecule

Adds local method for testing the validity of the modified
roles via molecule on supported platforms:

tox -e molecule

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-12 07:01:10.000000000', 'message': "Choose random value for HA routes' vr_id

HA routers are using keepalived and needs to have virtual_router_id
configured. As routers which belongs to same tenant are using same
ha network, those values have to be different for each router.

Before this patch this value was always taken as first available value
from available_vr_ids range.
In some (rare) cases, when more than one router is created in parallel
for same tenant it may happen that those routers would have same vr_id
choosen so keepalived would treat them as single application and only
one router would be ACTIVE on one of L3 agents.

This patch changes this behaviour that now random value from available
vr_ids will be chosen instead of taking first value always.
That should mittigate this rare race condition that it will be (almost)
not noticable for users.

However, proper fix should be probably done as some additional
constraint in database layer. But such solution wouldn't be possible to
backport to stable branches so I decided to propose this easy patch
first.

Conflicts:
    neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py

Change-Id: Idb0ed744e54976dca23593fb2d7317bf77442e65
Related-Bug: #1823314
(cherry picked from commit a8d0f557d504957aeb91f451105cca9eee2d6adb)
(cherry picked from commit ee2ed681c495c4fc5086d761853731b7dc2fd34f)
"}]
commit_message:
Choose random value for HA routes' vr_id

HA routers are using keepalived and needs to have virtual_router_id
configured. As routers which belongs to same tenant are using same
ha network, those values have to be different for each router.

Before this patch this value was always taken as first available value
from available_vr_ids range.
In some (rare) cases, when more than one router is created in parallel
for same tenant it may happen that those routers would have same vr_id
choosen so keepalived would treat them as single application and only
one router would be ACTIVE on one of L3 agents.

This patch changes this behaviour that now random value from available
vr_ids will be chosen instead of taking first value always.
That should mittigate this rare race condition that it will be (almost)
not noticable for users.

However, proper fix should be probably done as some additional
constraint in database layer. But such solution wouldn't be possible to
backport to stable branches so I decided to propose this easy patch
first.

Conflicts:
    neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py

Change-Id: Idb0ed744e54976dca23593fb2d7317bf77442e65
Related-Bug: #1823314
(cherry picked from commit a8d0f557d504957aeb91f451105cca9eee2d6adb)
(cherry picked from commit ee2ed681c495c4fc5086d761853731b7dc2fd34f)

commit_message:
Fix the problem of osd initialization failed

When deploying osd, if the user does not use the extra block
partition, the kolla will automatically partition the disk and then
clean up the data on the disk partition. Sometimes the disk partition
will not be updated, there will be an error not finding the partition.

This commit fixes the problem.

Change-Id: I14708f38614dcb75268c2f460ae3d921748c2d10
Closes-bug: #1824787
(cherry picked from commit ddab09fdd8d7c08ce8db70948ea12571bb4267a8)

commit_message:
Fix the problem of osd initialization failed

When deploying osd, if the user does not use the extra block
partition, the kolla will automatically partition the disk and then
clean up the data on the disk partition. Sometimes the disk partition
will not be updated, there will be an error not finding the partition.

This commit fixes the problem.

Change-Id: I14708f38614dcb75268c2f460ae3d921748c2d10
Closes-bug: #1824787
(cherry picked from commit ddab09fdd8d7c08ce8db70948ea12571bb4267a8)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-15 23:02:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix a lifecycle bug with child objects

In some edge cases, when a request comes in to update a child
resource (member, HM, or l7rule), the API would not always make
sure the parent object (pool or l7policy) was in a mutable status.

This patch fixes this by checking the parent provisioning_status
before allowing a muttable change on a child object.

It also resolves two cases where a parent object status was not being
reset on a reverted flow.

Change-Id: I86f76bebce0993215fd34ccd33251ba1e6c325a9
Story: 2005249
Task: 30043
'}, {'created': '2019-03-20 19:48:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix a lifecycle bug with child objects

This patch fixes this by checking the parent provisioning_status
before allowing a muttable change on a child object.

It also resolves two cases where a parent object status was not being

Change-Id: I86f76bebce0993215fd34ccd33251ba1e6c325a9
Story: 2005249

commit_message:
Fix a lifecycle bug with child objects

In some edge cases, when a request comes in to update a child
resource (member, HM, or l7rule), the API would not always make
sure the parent object (pool or l7policy) was in a mutable status.

This patch fixes this by checking the parent provisioning_status
before allowing a muttable change on a child object.

It also resolves two cases where a parent object status was not being
reset on a reverted flow.

Change-Id: I86f76bebce0993215fd34ccd33251ba1e6c325a9
Story: 2005249
Task: 30043

commit_message:
Correct the ovn option name for vhost socket directory

Actual ovn configuration is 'vhost_sock_dir' in networking-ovn
to set the vhostuser socket directory. Change the conf name
from vhostuser_socket_dir to the correct one.

Change-Id: I79130a21a31a589460724a4a68cfadb38ce4d26b

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I0bbb6bea3c1127e473db6c21666b9da1fbe4ab9c

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Idef6539c2662bf57b03f52292ee96ba9c6ada571

commit_message:
Add privileged add, replace and delete route

This change introduces possibility to use pyroute2 within
privileged part of ip_lib to add, replace and delete
routes.

Related-bug: #1492714
Change-Id: I357a75c0447e931f495ab4c6d32d9cf537047a53

[{'created': '2018-08-09 12:53:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix rebinding of "binding_failed" ports on startup

Since the switch to "CacheBackedPluginApi" the ovs-agent didn't try to
rebind ports at startup that were in the "binding_failed" state. This is
because the rebinding was triggered as part of the old implementation of
"get_device_details()" on the server side.

This commit changes the "CacheBackedPluginApi.get_device_details()" call
to fall back to the older implementation when encountering affected Ports.

Change-Id: Id453d85f392320ea852496c4a1c800558aa52dc8
Closes-bug: #1780453
'}]
commit_message:
Fix rebinding of "binding_failed" ports on startup

Since the switch to "CacheBackedPluginApi" the ovs-agent didn't try to
rebind ports at startup that were in the "binding_failed" state. This is
because the rebinding was triggered as part of the old implementation of
"get_device_details()" on the server side.

This commit changes the "CacheBackedPluginApi.get_device_details()" call
to fall back to the older implementation when encountering affected Ports.

Change-Id: Id453d85f392320ea852496c4a1c800558aa52dc8
Closes-bug: #1780453

[{'created': '2018-04-12 21:38:54.000000000', 'message': "ovs: survive errors when recovering from ovs restart

If ovs was restarted, and an error happens when resetting bridges /
tunnels / flows, the agent crashes and exits. To avoid that, we
make the agent catch all errors and gracefully ignore them (after
logging details), in hope that the next iteration will be more
successful.

Since we set up canary flows before the rest of _handle_ovs_restart
body, it's possible to receive an error after the flows are set on
bridges. In this case, the next iteration will return OVS_NORMAL from
check_canary_table(). We should handle this situation by forcing full
recovery after OVS restart. This is achieved by introducing the
``recover_needed`` boolean flag that serves as a sticky indication that
an OVS restart happened in the past that we haven't fully recovered
from.

Change-Id: I82597d731bcba38a67f29ba953ee3e14fd532020
Related-Bug: #1731494

commit_message:
ovs: survive errors when recovering from ovs restart

If ovs was restarted, and an error happens when resetting bridges /
tunnels / flows, the agent crashes and exits. To avoid that, we
make the agent catch all errors and gracefully ignore them (after
logging details), in hope that the next iteration will be more
successful.

Since we set up canary flows before the rest of _handle_ovs_restart
body, it's possible to receive an error after the flows are set on
bridges. In this case, the next iteration will return OVS_NORMAL from
check_canary_table(). We should handle this situation by forcing full
recovery after OVS restart. This is achieved by introducing the
``recover_needed`` boolean flag that serves as a sticky indication that
an OVS restart happened in the past that we haven't fully recovered
from.

Change-Id: I82597d731bcba38a67f29ba953ee3e14fd532020
Related-Bug: #1731494

commit_message:
Stop handling 'cell_name' field on Instance.save()

Nothing should be setting these anymore so we can removed it.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I97d5269b2837c996d294baabb1395e4d90cad070
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-22 10:12:55.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid get_object for small queries

We use neutron objects for
1) RPC between neutron components
2) passing them between functions across modules
3) converting the DB columns to dict and serialize

But for small queries which need only few columns from tables
(without joining other tables), directly querying the databse
will improve the performance.

Co-Authored-By: Joe Talerico <jtaleric@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7a0316d42b952b9be01c8b7e7db8177d899b8394
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid get_object for small queries

We use neutron objects for
1) RPC between neutron components
2) passing them between functions across modules
3) converting the DB columns to dict and serialize

But for small queries which need only few columns from tables
(without joining other tables), directly querying the databse
will improve the performance.

Co-Authored-By: Joe Talerico <jtaleric@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7a0316d42b952b9be01c8b7e7db8177d899b8394

Use Port OVO in neutron/db/external_net_db.py

This patch includes the Port OVO in neutron/db/external_net_db.py.

Change-Id: I153265b24fab4c4bca339acf23acef03244da172
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

'}, {'created': '2018-10-02 16:12:06.000000000', 'message': "Remove the loadbalancer policy rules

These policy rules are used by neutron lbaas which has been

commit_message:
Remove the loadbalancer policy rules

These policy rules are used by neutron lbaas which has been
splited out from neutron. In addition, the neutron-lbaas is
deprecated in flavor of octavia, but octavia doesn't use these
rules. This commit removes these rules from sample policy files.

Change-Id: I000e854f8e86a8cccfdc437b8fe0ee689e403229

commit_message:
Remove deprecated option split_branches from migration CLI

The 'split_branches' option in the migration CLI was deprecated in
Newton and scheduled for removal in Ocata.  This finally dispenses with
it.

Change-Id: I2f084a2fa7876bfd298429d9fa0784c269cb7f21

commit_message:
add vmware-nsx non voting py35 job

As per our PTG discussion, networking projects can add non-voting jobs
to neutron check queue as a means to smoke-screen failures introduced by
neutron patches.

This patch adds a non-voting job that runs vmware-nsx UTs with neutron
based on what the requirements repo does [2].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-September/135032.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/.zuul.d/cross-jobs.yaml

Change-Id: I4641a4e540635590c363a997cf8d20a02b7c24e0

In addition, retry_if_session_inactive is moving to neutron-lib: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/ed62a06a536a39b1236bd4dcadb2dd13cc2c4b4b/neutron_lib/db/api.py#L202 . We need another patch to openstack/neutron-lib to sync up the code.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-09-21 14:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-09-24 11:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I still strugling with it....
It happens at unit test run, during import time, example:
import neutron.tests.unit.tests.common.test_net_helpers
  class Tag(base.NeutronDbObject): 
  File "/home/elajkat/github/neutron/neutron/objects/tag.py", line 129, in Tag 
    def delete_objects(cls, context, validate_filters=True, **kwargs): 
  File "/home/elajkat/github/neutron/neutron/db/api.py", line 119, in decorator 
    raise e 
  File "/home/elajkat/github/neutron/neutron/db/api.py", line 113, in decorator 
    ctx_arg_index = p_util.getargspec(f).args.index(context_var_name) 
  File "/home/elajkat/github/neutron/.tox/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pecan/util.py", line 48, in getargspec 
    reverse=True 
  File "/home/elajkat/github/neutron/.tox/py35/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pecan/util.py", line 40, in <lambda> 
    six.callable(c.cell_contents) and 
ValueError: Cell is empty

If I try to import manually the previous module (I suppose some test runner, or wrapper do that), and add six.get_function_closure(f) to the retry_if_session_inactive decorator I get:
(<cell at 0x7ff1eaa90408: empty>,)

which I don't understand, so some more research is needed, if this is really the good track....'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-09-24 12:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think it is related to how python2 and python3 handles closures, I tried to reproduce the issue without neutron:
https://gist.github.com/elajkat/4b2f9ac9c9dcabe63ab6d2f94dcb224e

Shortly: six.get_function_closure in py27 gives back None, in py35 it gives back something like <cell at 0x7fbe60ec24c8: empty>.

And as pecan handles only None (https://github.com/pecan/pecan/blob/master/pecan/util.py#id=L20), we run into error.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-24 20:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-24 20:24:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> I think it is related to how python2 and python3 handles closures,
 > I tried to reproduce the issue without neutron:
 > https://gist.github.com/elajkat/4b2f9ac9c9dcabe63ab6d2f94dcb224e
 > 
 > Shortly: six.get_function_closure in py27 gives back None, in py35
 > it gives back something like <cell at 0x7fbe60ec24c8: empty>.
 > 
 > And as pecan handles only None (https://github.com/pecan/pecan/blob/master/pecan/util.py#id=L20),
 > we run into error.

I hit this error as well. It looks this is because the closure is not fully constructed yet when the decorator is called. I moved the call of getargspec further down to the wrapped function so that it won't be called until the closure is constructed."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-09-24 21:58:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build succeeded.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-13 14:24:23.000000000', 'message': "Move retry_if_session_inactive to tag OVO

Move db_api.retry_if_session_inactive decorator from tag_plugin
update_tags method to tag OVO delete_objects and create methods.

retry_if_session_inactive decorator looks for context variable
(context_var_name) in the decorated method's parameters.
As create has no parameter at all, only the self, the decorator changed
to make it capable of looking for self.context_variable.

Change-Id: I28d6154fbe274c24b9d2cdc4df90f611a5b5650f

commit_message:
Move retry_if_session_inactive to tag OVO

Move db_api.retry_if_session_inactive decorator from tag_plugin
update_tags method to tag OVO delete_objects and create methods as an
effort to move all dependencies to dp_api to OVO, see discussion here:
https://review.openstack.org/565773

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin.lu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I28d6154fbe274c24b9d2cdc4df90f611a5b5650f
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
Use OVO in neutron/ipam/subnet_alloc.py

Migrate to using Subnet and SubnetPool OVO objects in the IPAM subnet
allocation code.

This removes the test test_subnetpool_concurrent_allocation_exception
from the TestSubnetAllocation tests because that exception is no longer
generated in the objectified code path.

Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
Floating IPs should not allocate IPv6 addresses

When there are both IPv4 and IPv6 subnets on the public
network, the port that a floating IP allocates there gets
assigned addresses from both subnets.

Allocating an IPv6 address should be avoided for
neutron floating ip if those plugins not support
associating IPv6 floating IPs to IPv4 fixed IPs.

Change-Id: I229ccf1483bf284f6c7f329980c8f391efd4fae9
Closes-Bug: #1752903

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-21 20:13:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix create/update subnet segment_id not enforcing policy

This patch set fixes create_subnet:segment_id and
update_subnet:segment_id policies not getting enforced
by oslo.policy even though both are admin_only in
the policy file [0].

This was caught initially using RBAC tests [1] and also
confirmed using unit tests.

The bug is fixed by adding 'enforce_policy': True to
the segments extension.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/b16b890ec6067bd9ccca26e1312cb26d7f984ca9/etc/policy.json#L18
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582388/

Change-Id: I50bbc1825928090c0ffdea8bafe0378b80b56600
"}, {'created': '2018-07-27 18:16:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix create/update subnet segment_id not enforcing policy

commit_message:
Let Neutron enforce rule on create_subnet with segment_id [neutron part]

Neutron ignores rule in policy file [0], that allows non-admin users
to create subnets with segment_id.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/etc/policy.json#L19

Partial-Bug: 1784259
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/598334/
Change-Id: I50bbc1825928090c0ffdea8bafe0378b80b56600

[{'created': '2018-09-10 13:19:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Give back http403 for get without permission

Operation show (GET /v2.0/resources/uuid) gives back exceptionto the user
if the user has no right (based on policy.json) to fetch the resource.
For list operation (GET v2.0/resources) on the contrary gives back an
empty list, without giving any kind of feedback to the user.
In case the list is empty because there is no resource which can be
visible by the user there should be an error message (http 403 for
example).

TODO:
* Tests (unit, functional?)
* Is this really a bug?

commit_message:
WIP: Give back http403 for get without permission

Operation show (GET /v2.0/resources/uuid) gives back exceptionto the user
if the user has no right (based on policy.json) to fetch the resource.
For list operation (GET v2.0/resources) on the contrary gives back an
empty list, without giving any kind of feedback to the user.
In case the list is empty because there is no resource which can be
visible by the user there should be an error message (http 403 for
example).

TODO:
* Tests (unit, functional?)

Change-Id: Ie4e7d847ca6d404c2b96929b5bab649ab10c3b46
Closes-Bug: #1789499

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/581360/2 : SUCCESS in 1h 32m 57s'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-12-05 07:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-12-05 09:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

With this change you are going back to use "ip" commands.

I understand your problem and I suggest a different strategy: implement in IpNeighCommand class something like "add_bulk_neigh_entry". You can store in a variable a list of tuples (ip, mac, device_name, namespace) and, at the end of the subnet_ports loop, you can call this function. This new function will call the rootwrap context only once.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-12-05 09:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Do you have a bug filled in Launchpad? Please, add the ID in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-12-05 09:35:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/581360/3 : SUCCESS in 1h 42m 01s'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-12-05 14:04:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez,

If you wish to take over this patch, this would be wonderful. Indeed, I'm super busy with Debian packaging of all of OpenStack, my own installer OCI, and many other stuff, Debian related or not. Sharing this patch is already a lot of effort."}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2018-12-05 15:51:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I understand the problem this solves and I agree with taking a slightly different approach. Let's file a bug so this can proceed, it's attempting to solve a real scale issue."}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-12-06 15:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ryan Tidwell, and the others.

Thanks for the reviews!

Indeed, we did hit this scaling problem hard in production, as per the patch header. Without this patch, it takes up to 20 minutes for us in our deployment, between the time when we start the L3 agent, and the time when VMs can ping. This is really an unacceptable behavior for our final customers which we had to address.

I am very much open to any improvement to this patch, and for someone to take it over. However, here we have a typical case of an operator trying to upstream a patch (ie: myself), but having no time (and probably not enough skills and knowledge of the project) to make it up to shape for upstream. This has been discussed at large during the last summit in Berlin. Unless someone from the Neutron team takes it over and makes it work the team's way, this patch has a big chance of staying as a patch in our infrastructure only. Probably we all want to avoid this.

Also, I'd like to also highlight the fact that, if there's a problem with "ip neigh", there's also the same kind of problem with "ovs-vsctl add-flows". But in that particular thing, I was not able to find a way to avoid spawning all the instances of rootwrap in a patch, the way I attempted to do it here for "ip neigh add". It'd be super nice if someone could also investigate that scaling issue there as well, and pinpoint (at least to me) where the loop is happening, because I couldn't find the loop as I did for the "ip neigh add". It's kind of buried deep into the class/object model of Neutron, which isn't easy to find out without deeper analysis of the code. Again, the time I can grant for such task is very limited.'}, {'account_id': 4187, 'date': '2018-12-06 16:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thomas: Thanks for putting this patch together given your time constraints. If you could file a bug and document your findings (or anything that would help a developer who would be working on this), we should be able to find a way to move forward with a fix.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-12-07 14:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2018-12-07 14:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Rodolfo, Ryan,

I have filed this bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1807396

commit_message:
Speed-up ip neigh replace

With more than 1000 VMs in the same project, and 2 subnet in it (one for
ipv4 and one for ipv6), the l3 agent performs more than 4000 calls to ip
using rootwrap. This is a way too long, and can be replaced by some calls
to ip using the -batch option.

Closes-Bug: #1807396

Change-Id: Ic1c59a67aed6245b070640d7c63a8a96ac234279

commit_message:
Support vlan transparent network for ml2 ovs driver

Now, ovs was supports QinQ, this patch can support vlan
transparent for openvswitch Ml2 driver, when tenant create
network which has 'vlan transprent' property.

This patch uses the already existing property 'vlan_transparent'
of network to indicates that corresponding ovs port needs to be
configure to QinQ mode.

Change-Id: Id1ac60795bbc793ba0777e6a096177d6c1725ad6
Closes-bug: #1604222

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-12-21 08:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Regenerate process config files and parameters

For class ProcessManager, the parameters and config files are generated
by a callback function. This function generates config files and return
the command(with parameters). Sending HUP signal doesn't change
parameters, neither regenerate config files.

This patch is to ensure config files and parameters regenerated in
reload_cfg/restart.

Change-Id: I505676fe822b9cf33903a1de21e386568055478c
Closes-bug: #1809080

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-08 14:47:31.000000000', 'message': 'DEMO: illustrate how to integrate sqlalchemy "baked" query

The "baked" query system in SQLAlchemy caches the string
SQL statement for a particular Query-construction path.   As
some profiling in Neutron have observed 30-40% time spent in
constructing Query objects due to the many small "fetch-one-object"
style of query, the "baked" system may potentially be able to
greatly reduce this.

In Neutron, most queries come from _model_query(), so in order to
make this possible, all the hooks that feed into _model_query() would
need to provide "baked" versions of their processors.  In order to
allow the "baked" system to integrate gracefully without forcing
those external points to support it, this patch illustrates a system
by which each plugin point is tested for "baked" compatibility
and if not present we fall back to the regular _model_query.

Baked queries: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/extensions/baked.html

Change-Id: I695a81b22e7e4006094458d6238b814bd98b6d5d
'}, {'created': '2018-08-08 11:24:30.000000000', 'message': 'Use sqlalchemy baked query

In Neutron, most queries come from _model_query(), so in order to

by which each plugin point is tested for "baked" compatibility

Baked queries: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/extensions/baked.html

Change-Id: I695a81b22e7e4006094458d6238b814bd98b6d5d
'}]
commit_message:
Use sqlalchemy baked query

The "baked" query system in SQLAlchemy caches the string
SQL statement for a particular Query-construction path.   As
some profiling in Neutron have observed 30-40% time spent in
constructing Query objects due to the many small "fetch-one-object"
style of query, the "baked" system may potentially be able to
greatly reduce this.

In Neutron, most queries come from _model_query(), so in order to
make this possible, all the hooks that feed into _model_query() would
need to provide "baked" versions of their processors.  In order to
allow the "baked" system to integrate gracefully without forcing
those external points to support it, this patch illustrates a system
by which each plugin point is tested for "baked" compatibility
and if not present we fall back to the regular _model_query.

Baked queries: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/extensions/baked.html

Change-Id: I695a81b22e7e4006094458d6238b814bd98b6d5d

commit_message:
Fixes metering agent for DVR.

l3 agents on compute nodes get notifications now

iptable rules correctly applied for snat namespaces on controllers

iptables rules correctly applied for qrouter namespaces on computes

Slightly alternative design to
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/621165

Closes-Bug #1807157

Change-Id: Ie5e39d3c92560e7e21d76d00592130ad9ca0ec07

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-15 16:25:00.000000000', 'message': 'Enable liberal TCP connection tracking for SNAT namespaces

This can avoid connections randomly hanging due to tcp window
scaling not correctly being tracked. It should not have a large
effect otherwise.

Change-Id: I5e58bb2850bfa8e974e62215af0b4d7bc0592c13
'}, {'created': '2018-11-15 18:30:28.000000000', 'message': 'Enable liberal TCP connection tracking for SNAT namespaces

This can avoid connections randomly hanging due to tcp window
scaling not correctly being tracked.  This prevents packets
which are considered invalid by the connection tracking
from bein thrown out and allows the underlying TCP stack
recovery to function rather than stalling permanently.

Change-Id: I5e58bb2850bfa8e974e62215af0b4d7bc0592c13
'}, {'created': '2018-11-20 23:01:41.000000000', 'message': 'Enable liberal TCP connection tracking for SNAT namespaces

This can avoid connections rarely hanging due to tcp window
scaling not correctly being observed by the TCP connection
tracking. this seems to happen when retransmits are occurring
occassionally.
Setting this parameter turns off validating the window scaling
checks for the purpose of matching whether a packet matches
an existing connection tracked flow, which avoids the SNAT
namespace from interfering and letting the connection peers
recover the connection via retransmits/Selective ACKs instead
of the SNAT terminating one side of the connection and letting
it stall permanently.

Closes-Bug: #1804327
Change-Id: I5e58bb2850bfa8e974e62215af0b4d7bc0592c13
'}, {'created': '2018-12-18 19:52:21.000000000', 'message': 'Enable liberal TCP connection tracking for SNAT namespaces

This can avoid connections rarely hanging due to tcp window
scaling not correctly being observed by the TCP connection
tracking. this seems to happen when retransmits are occurring
occassionally.
Setting this parameter turns off validating the window scaling
checks for the purpose of matching whether a packet matches
an existing connection tracked flow, which avoids the SNAT
namespace from interfering and letting the connection peers
recover the connection via retransmits/Selective ACKs instead
of the SNAT terminating one side of the connection and letting
it stall permanently.

Closes-Bug: #1804327
Change-Id: I5e58bb2850bfa8e974e62215af0b4d7bc0592c13

commit_message:
Enable liberal TCP connection tracking for SNAT namespaces

This can avoid connections rarely hanging due to tcp window
scaling not correctly being observed by the TCP connection
tracking. this seems to happen when retransmits are occurring
occassionally.
Setting this parameter turns off validating the window scaling
checks for the purpose of matching whether a packet matches
an existing connection tracked flow, which avoids the SNAT
namespace from interfering and letting the connection peers
recover the connection via retransmits/Selective ACKs instead
of the SNAT terminating one side of the connection and letting
it stall permanently.

Closes-Bug: #1804327
Change-Id: I5e58bb2850bfa8e974e62215af0b4d7bc0592c13

> Lu - can you address Liu's questions?  Thanks

Hi, Brian. These days I have been busy with the company's product development, and I will test it again when I have time :)"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-02-11 14:25:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I tried to reproduce this bug injecting packets both from a VM and the router namespace.

If the transmission is limited (VM interface MTU), there are no re-transmissions or packets dropped. When executing iperf from the router namespace, I manually limit the packet size:

  iperf3 -c 192.168.222.2 --set-mss 2048 -l 2048  # MTU 2048

I tested several MTU sizes (2K, 9K and 64K), always limiting the write buffer size to a maximum of 64K. When the MSS size is fixed and the write buffer of iperf is limited, I don't see any performance reduction (BW is keep to the limit defined in the filter) and the number of retransmissions limited to a reasonable number. Another considerations are that there is no IP fragmentation and there are no requests back to reduce the window size (PMTUD is a router functionality)

About the packet size increase detected in [1], all I can say is that TC filter marks the packets using fwmarks. Those marks are part of the skb packet, not the IP packet or the ethernet frame itself [2].

Because no IPv4 packet must exceed the 64KB limitation, increasing this number in the filter makes no sense.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1785189/comments/5
[2] https://docs.huihoo.com/hpc-cluster/linux-virtual-server/HOWTO/LVS-HOWTO.fwmark.html#LVS-HOWTO.fwmark"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:47:38.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]

commit_message:
Fix bug when floatingip and router bandwidth speed limit failure

When set mtu value to 64kb， the egress bandwidth limit of the VM
and the routing gateway will be invalid. I have tested it many
times. When set mtu value to 70kb, the bandwidth limit is normal.

For more information, you can read as follow:
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1785189/comments/5

Change-Id: Id17ad136914dad937c4a8fa5ac0959eb833a26d1
Closes-Bug: #1785189

commit_message:
Remove duplicate  start for AllServicesNeutronWorker

This fixes a random unhealthy state in the neutron_api
as a result of duplicate start for PerodicWorker.

Change-Id: Ic462af66e77892b9ddce3d7828df144b9d9a1376
Close-bug: #1809823

 > When, during the wait() function (which is a blocking function),
 > are we killing the worker?

HI, stop function invoked in https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/master/oslo_service/service.py#L571
then wait function invoked in https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/master/oslo_service/service.py#L572

If wait function do not block, child will stop immediately'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-02-14 13:33:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I don't understand your answer. Where in the Neutron code are we, at the same time, calling "wait()" and "kill()"?

BTW, if you have detected this error, can you provide some error logs in the bug report?

If the greenthread is killed, the wait() function will return intermediately. I still don't understand the change in this function.'}, {'account_id': 10518, 'date': '2019-02-14 14:11:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I don't understand your answer. Where in the Neutron code are we,
 > at the same time, calling "wait()" and "kill()"?
 > 
 > BTW, if you have detected this error, can you provide some error
 > logs in the bug report?
 > 
 > If the greenthread is killed, the wait() function will return
 > intermediately. I still don't understand the change in this
 > function.

I have updated bug description to add my debug process.
Because the wsgi use greenthread pool, Neutron WorkerService use the greenthread to start wsgi.
I didn't  go deep into the greenthread, but it seems kill and then wait works in my testing.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2019-02-14 19:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10518, 'date': '2019-02-15 10:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-02-15 12:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/636855/3 : FAILURE in 1h 39m 35s'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-02-17 18:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-02-17 20:39:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

My concerns/request with this patch are:
- A worker thread should not have access to other workers. The implementation in PS1 exceeds the scope of a WorkerService, handling other workers thread. WorkerService._server is just one single thread and should be not aware of other ones.

- If there is a problem with the synchronization between threads, this should be solved in wsgi.Server().

When the server is launched, wsgi.Server() uses ProcessLauncher to spawn several processes. ProcessLauncher waits in an infinite loop in _start_child() while the process is running.

wsgi.wait() calls ProcessLauncher.wait() function. This function will wait and respawn all processes if needed, until SIGTERM is sent.

wsgi.stop() calls ProcessLauncher.stop() function, which kills all spawned children.


In a nutshell:
- It makes sense the change in the stop() function
- But not the modification of wait() function.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-02-19 13:04:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10518, 'date': '2019-02-26 04:13:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

Hi  Rodolfo,
I use a test script to test kill and wait. please check: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/jesse-eventlet-wsgi-test

After server.kill(), ongoing requests do not stop until they got response from server, then server.wait() will raise greenlet.GreenletExit exception.
It seems it's not clear for the doc: http://eventlet.net/doc/modules/greenthread.html#eventlet.greenthread.GreenThread.kill

@Yulong
I also test this pool.resize(0), It seems if there is no pool.resize(0), after server.kill(), the new requests do not work.
I'm curious about this pool.resize(0)..."}, {'account_id': 10518, 'date': '2019-02-26 06:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

There is other issue related to this fix, I updated in bug, please check: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1815871/comments/4
Do we need to address this issue in my comment?'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:47:17.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]

commit_message:
Graceful shutdown for neutron-server api worker

We need wait neutron-server api finish all it's requests
in wait function.

Change-Id: Ief99998513634f0e65ed83962342c739e04e6051
Closes-Bug: #1815871

commit_message:
Increase lease file buffering for dnsmasq lease reads

The default buffer of 4k is too small for larger envs, so
we frequently hit a race. Increase to 64k, which shouldn't
be too much of an overhead and still cover most cases.

Change-Id: I4d88c7e0d378bedb9aac2a42555d35295f447caf
Partial-Bug: #1788556

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-12 16:38:05.000000000', 'message': "WIP Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

TODO tests

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
"}, {'created': '2018-12-13 13:08:25.000000000', 'message': "Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/637935
"}]
commit_message:
Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/637935

commit_message:
[WIP] Add native OVSDB implementation for polling monitor

TODO: remove prints and extra logs for debugging

This patch implements an OVS interface monitor based in the OVSDB
native implementation (OVSDB IDL, Open vSwitch Database Interface
Definition Language).

Closes-Bug: #1789592

Change-Id: I41651cafa21b90d3d07a2da882d35a762f29a727

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I160c141169d68fd9403604c68cecde0c70c463c3

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-07 04:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think we've got a communications disconnect here.

in neutron-lib, the set_proctitle argument is used to turn on/off the feature. It's valid values are "on", "off", and "brief". It has a default value of "on".

There are also name and desc arguments. They also have default values, and can be safely passed with None (there's even a unit test to that effect.)

An older version of neutron that has the new lib will work fine.

The CONF stack exception refers to the CONF variable in _neutron_. The *only* way you could have code that references CONF.set_proctitle and not have it set is if you're somehow getting the new service.py/worker.py from *neutron*, and you didn't also get the conf/common.py change *from the same patch*.

Something else is going on here. A newer neutron with an older neutron-lib would result in errors of passing args that don't exist.

An older neutron with a newer neutron-lib should work fine.

I don't see how a missing cfg.CONF value can be fixed by passing in args to the lib... ??'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-07 04:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

"safely passed with None", I meant "safely passed with None or not at all".'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-07 04:25:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

If you can find me on IRC, @dougwig, let's talk there."}, {'account_id': 27215, 'date': '2019-03-07 07:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I think we've got a communications disconnect here.
 > 
 > in neutron-lib, the set_proctitle argument is used to turn on/off
 > the feature. It's valid values are "on", "off", and "brief". It has
 > a default value of "on".
 > 
 > There are also name and desc arguments. They also have default
 > values, and can be safely passed with None (there's even a unit
 > test to that effect.)
 > 
 > An older version of neutron that has the new lib will work fine.
 > 
 > The CONF stack exception refers to the CONF variable in _neutron_.
 > The *only* way you could have code that references
 > CONF.set_proctitle and not have it set is if you're somehow getting
 > the new service.py/worker.py from *neutron*, and you didn't also
 > get the conf/common.py change *from the same patch*.
 > 
 > Something else is going on here. A newer neutron with an older
 > neutron-lib would result in errors of passing args that don't
 > exist.
 > 
 > An older neutron with a newer neutron-lib should work fine.
 > 
 > I don't see how a missing cfg.CONF value can be fixed by passing in
 > args to the lib... ??
Hi! look here https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640704/

I have use the newest neutron-lib version and the master neutron

it also failed. Look like it is nouse. But if I add this pr change 

in myself test envirment. It is ok to pass all.'}, {'account_id': 27215, 'date': '2019-03-07 07:48:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I join the openstack-meeting but do not see you there.:)"}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-03-07 10:05:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

But if you merge this change in your own laptop. Out test can pass all!It is all no problem.'}, {'account_id': 27215, 'date': '2019-03-12 06:13:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Your unit tests had a bug. Please see my referenced change.
Oh yes.look like also have other effect. I will have a look.Thank you!'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-12 15:19:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> But if you merge this change in your own laptop. Out test can pass all!It is all no problem.

If you're suggesting we merge this change to make your tests pass, then I'm not going to support that. Using the neutron config without initializing the neutron config is why you're having issues. That must be addressed. And it looks like you have some problems due to other interface changes as well.

It looks like tricircle and neutron might need to have a more formal conversation about interface contracts, and get those interfaces moved into neutron-lib, as the way it's being used now is likely to result in future breakages."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:45:47.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]

commit_message:
the PeriodicWorker class init misssing desc argument

After this pr merged,https://review.openstack.org/#/c/637019/
we should add the default desc in PeriodicWorker class. Otherwise
some class based on the PeriodicWorker which does not set the
setproctitle =off in neutorn.conf will get an exception.
like below, where set_proctitle is None and there is no
setproctitle config

Closes-Bug:#1818765

Change-Id: Ib3e0273308b1c7824a1bd78a51b826e429d38fa4

commit_message:
Integration of (Distributed) Port Binding OVO

This patch integrates Port Binding OVO in /plugins/ml2/db.py
and /plugins/ml2/plugin.py.

Change-Id: Ic70374aa75b151b7a06e640e397d8718450bc9c5
Co-Authored-By: Artur Korzeniewski <artur.korzeniewski@intel.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

Or am I misunderstanding how the privileged kill works?  If we can do it by pid, is privsep verifying the name?'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-03-04 04:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/639375/3 : SUCCESS in 1h 41m 32s'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-04 07:20:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Or am I misunderstanding how the privileged kill works?  If we can
 > do it by pid, is privsep verifying the name?

Yes, rootwrap's KillFilter works with pid and will check if process which You wan't to kill is actually process which You are allowed to kill. See https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/oslo_rootwrap/filters.py#L153"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-04 07:22:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Still functional tests issues looks like related to this patch'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-09 15:47:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-09 15:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-03-09 17:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/639375/4 : SUCCESS in 1h 34m 52s'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-11 18:44:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I spent time yesterday working on getting this approach (use setproctitle to change the state monitor name) working. Here's what I've found:

1) I can change the name of the process (note that python is not there anymore):

vagrant  15516  0.0  1.3 258036 82196 ?        S    01:23   0:00 neutron-keepalived-state-change --router_id=89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb --namespace=snat-89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb --conf_dir=/opt/stack/data/neutron/ha_confs/89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb --monitor_interface=ha-adf3c515-50 --monitor_cidr=169.254.0.1/24 --pid_file=/opt/stack/data/neutron/external/pids/89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb.monitor.pid --state_path=/opt/stack/data/neutron --user=1000 --group=1000

2) However, please see how the kill filter determines the name of the program to be killed: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/oslo_rootwrap/filters.py#L194-L210. If I run this sequence of instructions in the process shown above in point 1, I get the following:

>>> import os
>>> pid = 15516
>>> command = os.readlink("/proc/%d/exe" % int(pid))
>>> command = command.partition('\0')[0]
>>> command
'/usr/bin/python2.7'
>>> os.path.isfile(command)
True

So even though I have changed the the process cmdline, at the moment of finding the filter for the kill command, we are stuck with python. Any suggestions?

It seems to me that the alternatives are:

1) Go with the python filters
2) I can create a new executable, kill-state-change-monitor, add a filter to enable  to enable it and change the code in the ha router to invoke this executable, instead of sending a kill command.

What are your thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-11 21:15:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Miguel - bummer.  After looking at the code I guess I'd suggest a question to openstack-discuss ?  It almost seems like if /proc/$pid/cmdline differs from /proc/$pid/exe (i.e. not cmdline.startswith(command)) that the first should be returned as the command.  I'm not sure if there's some security reason you wouldn't want to do that, but maybe someone has an opinion.

See my untested hack at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/642569/

... but beware that there is still an issue with PATH (see ^^^)"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-11 21:30:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I spent time yesterday working on getting this approach (use
 > setproctitle to change the state monitor name) working. Here's what
 > I've found:
 > 
 > 1) I can change the name of the process (note that python is not
 > there anymore):
 > 
 > vagrant  15516  0.0  1.3 258036 82196 ?        S    01:23   0:00
 > neutron-keepalived-state-change --router_id=89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb
 > --namespace=snat-89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb
 > --conf_dir=/opt/stack/data/neutron/ha_confs/89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb
 > --monitor_interface=ha-adf3c515-50 --monitor_cidr=169.254.0.1/24
 > --pid_file=/opt/stack/data/neutron/external/pids/89938231-7754-4652-b48c-aef85eb38bbb.monitor.pid
 > --state_path=/opt/stack/data/neutron --user=1000 --group=1000
 > 
 > 2) However, please see how the kill filter determines the name of
 > the program to be killed: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/oslo_rootwrap/filters.py#L194-L210.
 > If I run this sequence of instructions in the process shown above
 > in point 1, I get the following:
 > 
 > >>> import os
 > >>> pid = 15516
 > >>> command = os.readlink("/proc/%d/exe" % int(pid))
 > >>> command = command.partition('\0')[0]
 > >>> command
 > '/usr/bin/python2.7'
 > >>> os.path.isfile(command)
 > True
 > 
 > So even though I have changed the the process cmdline, at the
 > moment of finding the filter for the kill command, we are stuck
 > with python. Any suggestions?
 > 
 > It seems to me that the alternatives are:
 > 
 > 1) Go with the python filters
 > 2) I can create a new executable, kill-state-change-monitor, add a
 > filter to enable  to enable it and change the code in the ha router
 > to invoke this executable, instead of sending a kill command.
 > 
 > What are your thoughts?

How about go with python filters for now, with come FIXME note for now and also report this as a bug/rfe to Oslo.rootwrap project? IMO it should be possible to specify also script which is run by e.g. python executable in such filter.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-12 03:23:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm also surprised that they're not using cmdline. And I'm ok with using python for now, as that's what some of the distros are inserting for us anyway."}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-12 03:33:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think I see, it's trying to match up executable paths, which cmdline won't have if it was a PATH search. Hmm, I wonder if we need to add a new type of KillFilter, like KillRegexpFilter or something."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-12 12:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You saw my oslo.rootwrap patch right? :)'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-12 15:12:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

No, but I see it now!  I was partway through doing a similar patch, when I realized why they were looking at exe and not cmdline in the first place.'}, {'account_id': 10980, 'date': '2019-03-13 00:48:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I have no idea if they'll accept it, but...

remote: New Changes:        
remote:   https://review.openstack.org/642932 Add a kill regexp filter"}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-13 04:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I updated https://review.openstack.org/#/c/636710 with filters for Python, so we can move ahead for the purposes of our RC-1. When / if the oslo guys accept Dougs patch, we can revisit and update accordingly'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:45:22.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]

commit_message:
Set keepalived command name

In order to be able to kill the keepalived state change monitor, we set
its command name to a known constant.

Change-Id: I4e99bfd095bdb1f7959478aa76751c1c24c3c4e2
Partial-Bug: #1795870

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/628493/1/neutron/agent/l3/namespaces.py'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:02:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm however not convinced the global option in l3 agent config is what we want. I.e we don't need the helper's on all routers. I'm writing up something on the ML thread."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-03-15 14:23:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

I need to re-test this. Someone else reported it is'nt working, need to check if I had some config contamination on my test node."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-03-15 15:05:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

$ cat /proc/sys/net/netfilter/nf_conntrack_helper
0

$ grep ^ct_target_rules /etc/neutron/l3_agent.ini
ct_target_rules = {helper: tftp, proto: udp, port: 69}

$ sudo ip netns exec qrouter-f67dd6a8-174e-4b85-9582-e22c1be49adf /sbin/iptables -t raw -L PREROUTING
Chain PREROUTING (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
neutron-l3-agent-PREROUTING  all  --  anywhere             anywhere            
CT         udp  --  anywhere             anywhere             udp dpt:tftp CT helper tftp


Once the rule is there, TFTP transfer of the boot ramdisk works.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-03-15 22:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/643570/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 49m 26s'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:45:15.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-15 12:39:10.000000000', 'message': 'WiP/PoC - Router Namespace - Connection Tracker helper

!! This is a PoC only.

In Bionic the nf_conntrack_helper is disabled by default.
This is good security practice, but causes issues for
Ironic CI which need conntrack for TFTP traffic.

The solution seem to be to add firewall rules to the
router namespace to explicitly enable the tftp helper
for the specific port. Example:

 -A PREROUTING -p udp -m udp --dport 69 -j CT --helper tftp

This change adds a config option in l3_agent which allow
specifying a list of dics such as:
  {helper: tftp, proto: udp, port: 69}

The data is then used to apply the firewall rules in the
namespace when it is created.

Change-Id: I88b45799265b8fafcae37f0f0fb0f1106efb1a06
'}]
commit_message:
WiP/PoC - Router Namespace - Connection Tracker helper

!! This is a PoC only.

In Bionic the nf_conntrack_helper is disabled by default.
This is good security practice, but causes issues for
Ironic CI which need conntrack for TFTP traffic.

The solution seem to be to add firewall rules to the
router namespace to explicitly enable the tftp helper
for the specific port. Example:

 -A PREROUTING -p udp -m udp --dport 69 -j CT --helper tftp

This change adds a config option in l3_agent which allow
specifying a list of dics such as:
  {helper: tftp, proto: udp, port: 69}

The data is then used to apply the firewall rules in the
namespace when it is created.

Change-Id: I88b45799265b8fafcae37f0f0fb0f1106efb1a06

Switch to current hacking

We can also remove that from test-requirements to avoid this
being pulled in for unit tests - it is a stylistic checking tool
only.

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ib04cb5c282eb8e07210ef83676213e41b629f889

commit_message:
rehome policy and cache_utils

Today we have neutron_lib._policy that is 1/2 baked, out of sync and was
never consumed.

This patch updates neutron_lib's policy with the latest from neutron
with the following changes:
- Removed TODO about API attribute typing; we have that IIUC.
- Removed NOTE about _extract() relying on core plugin; we now have the
plugin directory in neutron-lib which IIUC solves this NOTE.
- Removed the 'plugin' kwarg from enforce() and check(). This kwarg is
deprecated and not used by the functions. Now is the time to clean it
up.

In addition neutron.common.cache_utils is rehomed as
neutron_lib.utils.cache. While not used outside neutron today [1], it's
needed by policy and generic in nature.

TEMP TESTING PATCH for neutron consumption:
Depends-On: I300323961a35385e597d803348ca2f877ee55fdd

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron.common%20import%20cache_utils

Change-Id: I788d3c4080fb7ef3f2c1edf1ea3d955f81634732

commit_message:
rehome securitygroup api def

This patch rehomes the security group API definition. Note that as part
of the rehome a handful of the error messages used on its API validation
and conversion have changed (not the response codes) as a result of
using generic validators/converters rather than 1-off API specific
functions.

A unit test and release note area also included.

Depends-On: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
Change-Id: I9466274a5236645471c1d0aab5c692b4728b8c6c

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-04 22:50:10.000000000', 'message': "support custom exceptions for api validation

Today the exception class used when attribute validation fails is
defined by the API itself when calling neutron_lib to validate data
in neutron_lib.api.attributes.AttributeInfo.convert_values. While
this makes sense most of time, there are cases when api definitions
want to override this default exception.

A classic example is an API extension pre-creates a resource upon
start-up; and this resource name is off-limits to API users. In such
a case the extension may want raise an InUse exception, rather than
a InvalidInput exception to signify the behavior.

This is done today, for example, in neutron's security group extension's
name_not_default validator [1]. Here users cannot create security groups
with any form of the name 'default' and it's enforced at the API
validation level. To signify a custom exception is used which translates
into a 409 HTTP response code rather than the default 400 otherwise.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py#L197

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
"}, {'created': '2017-12-04 22:54:20.000000000', 'message': "support custom exceptions for api validation

Today the exception class used when attribute validation fails is
defined by the API itself when calling neutron_lib to validate data
in neutron_lib.api.attributes.AttributeInfo.convert_values. While
this makes sense most of time, there are cases when api definitions
want to override this default exception.

A classic example is an API extension pre-creates a resource upon
start-up; and this resource name is off-limits to API users. In such
a case the extension may want raise an InUse exception, rather than
a InvalidInput exception to signify the behavior.

This is done today, for example, in neutron's security group extension's
name_not_default validator [1]. Here users cannot create security groups
with any form of the name 'default' and it's enforced at the API
validation level. To signify a custom exception is used which translates
into a 409 HTTP response code rather than the default 400 otherwise.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py#L197

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
"}, {'created': '2017-12-08 20:52:47.000000000', 'message': "support custom exceptions for api validation

As part of adding API definitions to neutron-lib, we want to reuse the
generic validators as much as possible. However as part of this reuse
we shouldn't impact the ability of an API to provide more meaningful
validation error messages that ultimately may ease the API user
experience. Moreover some API's need to customize the HTTP code returned
on validation failure [1].

Today we don't provide a way to customize the generic validator
exceptions/messages, so API's who need more specific error messages
(ex: [1][2]) only have the option to create 1-off validators for
their specific exceptions/messages.

This patch proposes that we allow APIs to customize this exception
class/message by having validators encapsulate their validation
failure data into an object that can then be used by a custom
exception. In addition a basic set of objects are provided to
implement the notion of validation results, options, etc.

Existing style validators that just return a string will still work,
but will be limited in terms of how useful they are for customized
exceptions. To that end this patch updates all lib's validators to use
the new style objects and clarifies that validators should not raise
exceptions unless they are programmatic in nature.

NeutronCoreInputNeeded

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/subnet_service_types.py

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
"}]
commit_message:
support custom exceptions for api validation

As part of adding API definitions to neutron-lib, we want to reuse the
generic validators as much as possible. However as part of this reuse
we shouldn't impact the ability of an API to provide more meaningful
validation error messages that ultimately may ease the API user
experience. Moreover some API's need to customize the HTTP code returned
on validation failure [1].

Today we don't provide a way to customize the generic validator
exceptions/messages, so API's who need more specific error messages
(ex: [1][2]) only have the option to create 1-off validators for
their specific exceptions/messages.

This patch proposes that we allow APIs to customize this exception
class/message by having validators encapsulate their validation
failure data into an object that can then be used by a custom
exception. In addition a basic set of objects are provided to
implement the notion of validation results, options, etc.

Existing style validators that just return a string will still work,
but will be limited in terms of how useful they are for customized
exceptions. To that end this patch updates all lib's validators to use
the new style objects and clarifies that validators should not raise
exceptions unless they are programmatic in nature.

NeutronCoreInputNeeded

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/subnet_service_types.py

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e

commit_message:
WIP: Rehome libnetfilter_log to neutron-lib

libnetfilter_log is a python binding for netfilter_log API. This library
will be used for firewall group, security group (firewall driver based
iptables) and snat logging to capture packets.

Change-Id: I681f42fb730ad137d47160fc397e03edc1631dfa

Sure thing.  You had asked for some buy-in from others on this approach, so I just wanted to signify my opinion. :-)"}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-01-07 16:00:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Looking a bit more into this; rehoming the test_base [1] for the corresponding objects.base.py herein isn't as easy as I'd hoped. The problem is that BaseDbObjectTestCase uses a number of the actual neutron.objects. modules and we don't want neutron-lib to have  dependency on these.


My current thinking is to separate out [1] into BaseDbObjectTestCase and some of its support logic and leave that in neutron. Consumers could then use the object registry to load BaseDbObjectTestCase if they need it, just like they should be doing to load any neutron.objects already. The remainder of [1] should then be rehomable into neutron-lib and focus on testing the objects.base module herein.


Anybody have thoughts on this approach?


[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/unit/objects/test_base.py"}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-01-11 20:55:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > and some of its support logic and leave that in neutron. Consumers
 > could then use the object registry to load BaseDbObjectTestCase if
 > they need it, just like they should be doing to load any
 > neutron.objects already. The remainder of [1] should then be
 > rehomable into neutron-lib and focus on testing the objects.base
 > module herein.
 >
 >
 > Anybody have thoughts on this approach?
 >
 >
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/unit/objects/test_base.py

This makes sense to me, in fact I think it's the only way to proceed.  So we would also have neutron.tests.base.BaseTestCase accessible through the registry as well, so that it could be testable?"}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-02-13 17:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-02-13 17:40:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-02-13 21:49:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-02-13 21:53:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

I took a stab a separating out the base object tests as discussed in previous comments.
While it was possible, it was necessary also pull along all the rbac objects/db and their dependencies.
As shown in the latest patch herein; it's a lot of code.


I think it's worth getting some more input at this point from the drivers team.
I don't need a code review of this, but rather inspection/approval that from a high-level we want to bring all this over into neutron-lib.
If we decide to do it, likely it would best be delivered in chunks rather than a single huge patch like this one."}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2019-02-13 22:19:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I created a placeholder RFE to try and get some driver team buy-in on this patch: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1815827'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-04-16 08:41:14.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 weeks without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. Feel free to reactivate the review by pressing the restore button and leaving a 'recheck' comment to get fresh test results."}]

commit_message:
WIP: rehome neutron.objects.base and deps

There are a number of consumers today who use neutron.objects.base
[1] and it's conceivable others may need it as OVO is adopted. This
patch rehomes neutron.objects.base and its dependencies and also
includes a test fixture for mocking out the neutron.objects.db.api CRUD
functions.

For a sample consumption patch see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/620999

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron.objects%20import%20base

Change-Id: I8173c59f26c3a52ea9abf52a58b64a82e1599466

commit_message:
Use unstable_test decorator from neutron-lib

As unstable_test is available in neutron-lib/utils/test.py.
This patch updates the plugin to consume unstable_test from
neutron-lib.

Change-Id: I3aaefa5dc38b5079cdbd98d4ac89df0d03f99eae

'}, {'created': '2018-11-05 11:17:09.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor QoS test to make it more reliable

Try to fix some problems and code quality of QoS related tests:
- implement delete_qos_policy method in API base test class and make
  sure it is called to delete QoS policies using the same client used
  to create them (as for other resource type)
- Move QoS floating IP scenario test to QoS test_qos.py test as it uses
  the same base code as the test there (this semplifies and reduces the
  code)
- Fix QoS policies leaks in scenario tests using API base test methdos.
- Implement standalone bash script to test download bandwith with a
  remote server using ncat tool from nmap project (only available on
  advanced images)
- Patch network client to allow creating policies without the optional
  parameter is_default (because it requires qos-default extension)
- Install nmap packace inside Ubuntu guest images 

Change-Id: I6eb5e451da2ffb1915c44dcc2354978e56321e4e
